Honestly? No, I don't recommend this game.
But I also kind of do. Let's get into why:

I had a lot of fun at first, taking out armies on horseback with a bow. Horse archer is ridiculously overpowered and it's genuinely a blast. If you want to dynasty warriors your way through an army, use a bow.
So why does the game suck?
Because the game encourages you to join an army. Armies are terrible.

I joined the Vaegirs (Still not sure how it's pronounced, Vaguer?) King Yaroglek is a worthless old fool who deserves to crumble to dust under his armour. I played a female character and he said that because I was a woman, I wouldn't get any fiefs.. Thanks game, blatant sexism is wonderful. I know the game strives for a supposed realism, but it fails in so many regards. Not to mention that it's not on earth... they developers chose to make their games historical setting be filled with all the bads of our worlds. 

Fun things in a historical setting: Swords, Shields, Horses, Bows, taking lords prisoner and making their kingdoms pay a fortune to get them back, then catching them again. Muahaha!

Bad things: Sexism, slavery, racism*, not being able to just say "no, this castle is mine now, I put in all the effort to take it."
*I don't know if coincidence or racism, but my character was dark skinned kind of a Greek tone, and an NPC referred to her as ugly and sunburnt... Could be a coincidence, but it does come off really badly.

I hate sexism, if I could turn that off, that'd be great. But despite this, I played the game anyway, he did give me a castle, so it was just a sexist comment that didn't mean anything... it just didn't need to be there at all.

Anyway: I wound up taking out almost all of the Swadian kingdoms. Their counts knew me straight away as someone to be feared. It was awful to do because through so much of it, my army fell short. The troops I commanded were fine, for the most part. Often they wouldn't join me in full force during sieges, you have to turn the troop count up in the settings.

Every time I took a castle, going through a lot of effort to do so. Yaroglek, the doddering old prelude to dust, would give it to someone else. I got one castle, out of the dozen I conquered. I got a bad one too. Not one of the cities, just some obscure keep in the middle of nowhere. Seriously devs, why are you giving the reward to NPCs? Give it to the player, the player actually exists, the NPCs do not.

I got to the last Swadian keep, I had to build a siege tower, which involved waiting for ages. It was finally built, we were out of money, food, morale was low. But I charged anyway. We took out all but 20 of their troops, but we were out of troops and I was out of arrows. So I retreated, I thought, let's go in again straight after, like you can do with every other battle in the game when you run out of arrows...
I had to build the siege tower again... 
I would've had to wait 60 (In game still a while) hours.
Their counts came and attacked me while I did that. They surrounded me at the edge of the map (That it doesn't indicate) and killed me. 

That was the end for me, I gave up.
I'd gone through so much effort. I'd taken their entire kingdom. You cannot kill counts, so I tried to imprison them, but they always get free again.
Where's that realism now? Why can't I execute them? Why am I releasing them, so they can go make another army to attack me? You'll allow sexism but not executions? Let me cut Montewar's head off and trebuchet it into his castle! (Game also lacks trebuchets, would not recommend based on that alone).

My army was never there for me, they never helped me, they ignored me when I was in trouble.
They took all the credit and got all the rewards.

If you play the game anyway:
Play female anyway, the game doesn't like it, but if you're not joining a kingdom, then you can show them who's boss.
Do not join a kingdom, become empress of all of Calradia, the kingdoms are all lead by weak simpering fools.
Savour the time before you get an army, armies make things stressful. Enjoy kicking butt before you do.

When the game hits that loop of "Oh no, this again"... stop playing. Do not go for the achievements. Trying to wipe out every kingdom is exhausting. I got exhausted wiping out ONE kingdom. Just one. If I had to take them all out I'd probably have started drinking heavily. This game gets really stressful. You're looking at 20-30 hours to take out one kingdom, if you're as slow as I was. If you're fast, maybe do it in 10-15. This is a huge time investment. For what might well wind up being nothing. Know when to stop. Take breaks. Don't blitz through the whole thing in one sitting. You will burn out very quickly and hate every minute of it.

Tech issues:
The game has an edge of the map, it doesn't tell you where the edge is, it's not indicated. So if you're running on horse away from someone else on horse, shooting back at them... Eventually you will hit the edge (Or a tree, but that's my fault) There's no way to tell where the edge of the map is.
It's very easy to get turned around in combat and get lost, a compass would've been nice. Less realistic? Make it look like a sundial or something. (I did wind up using the sun to tell direction, but often it's not there to help you.)

Sometimes enemies spawn mid air. They attack you, from mid air, they shoot arrows, mid air. It's a good thing I played an archer. But if I was using a polearm or a sword or something, this would've sucked big time.

Building siege equipment is boring. It takes ages, it takes ages of real life time.

While pillaging a village (I tend not to do this, I dislike killing civilians in any game) you cannot stop until the village is done... however the NPC's can stop pillaging to run after you. This is blatantly unfair and badly designed.

When sneaking into a town, you cannot have armour under your disguise, you cannot sneak in a decent weapon. You go in with no armour and a stick for a weapon, if you get caught, you have to fight a really unfair fight. And you're going to get caught. Extreme lack of fairness. (Best counter I can think of, get your weapon master up a bit and spec into polearms, if you're not already using them.)

You cannot choose your weapon for tournaments. You could be using a bow while they have a sword and are right up in your face making you "hiccup", completely unable to draw an arrow because they are in your face hitting you. Or you could be stuck with a lance, which is god awful to use. Give me some agency here, tournaments can be a lot of fun if you win... but losing them just feels like such a wasted effort.

There are other things I could complain about, but this is going on long enough.

TL:DR: I dunno, I had a bad time and gave the game a negative review based on that? Isn't that all negative reviews? 
Ultimately whether you want to play it is entirely up to you. I personally recommend against it because it takes ages. But if you want to play it, then I hope you have fun. I hope you enjoy it more than I did.
I tried my best to enjoy this game, but In the end, I'd give it a 4/10. It's not completely terrible, but it's still in the do not recommend, numbers. It stressed me out to no end and I wound up, ultimately, not enjoying myself.
I hope you do, regardless of your choice.

This game is old.  There's no denying that, graphical and gameplay flaws included.  However, after years of continued play, I would say it's "too much fun."  You control every aspect of your journey in the game: who/where you fight, if you engage in commerce or become a ruffian who fights everyone.  When you do something like storm or defend a city, you hold onto those moments, and feel like you actually changed something in the game world.  You start to recognize lords after a while in the field, and feel like you're following the politics of a kingdom by watching who defects or gets fiefs.  Creating your own kingdom is HARD, but that's by design, and you feel absolutely triumphant when you pull it off.

All in all, it's a game that wears its age on its sleeve, but it's just so well done that I have never regretted any of the hours I've put into it, and I know for sure I will put plenty more.

Pro - Awesome combat. You can scale battles from very small (with large armies) to full on cavalry charges with archer support and infantry. You can assign call outs to each group. Awesome sandbox strategy game. Become a lord. Build up your honor and right to rule while under a King's protection... then break away and wage war on everyone. 
Cons - This game had dated graphics when it came out. The graphics have not held up very well. If you can stomach T.E.S. Oblivion style graphics with extremely fun game-play then look no further from your next time sink.
In summary: Graphics bad... everything else AWESOME. If you can get it on sale it is one of the best values in the gaming industry. I've sunk hundreds of hours into RPG's like Skyrim and Cyberpunk - but over the years and consoles and PC's I've sunk thousands of hours here. If you can get it on sale think of play time literally costing you less than a penny per hour of enjoyment.

Wow. For a game that is rated "Overwhelmingly Positive", I expected a lot better. There is no explanation on how to do ANYTHING. There's a "tutorial", but it basically doesn't teach you anything, and just asks you to hit stuff and then tells you "good job!". I started a new game, confident that I would be able to figure out everything else on my own. Immediately there is a bandit attacking me and for SOME REASON I can't use my sword. Started with a crossbow as well, so I tried shooting him. Jokes on me, you have to stand still to reload it. So I decided to just start punching him. Killed me. Okay, I respawned in the next area. No big deal. Oh, NOW I can use my sword. Cool, must have been a glitch. No worries. Ok, now it tells me after getting my first quest to exit. I exit. Find some "looters". Cool, let's test out my sword skills. Load into a big open area with battle music, no enemies in sight. Ride around for like 10 minutes, still no enemies. Oh, what's this coming over the hill? There they are, finally! I will just charge them and hit them with my - OH GREAT, can't use my sword again. Neat, let's try a bunch of buttons to see what does what, maybe it's a mechanic of the game. WHAT- did I just drop my shield? Well, wasn't able to use my crossbow either, but now I can since I dropped my shield. Wow, these horse controls are AWFUL. Oh nice, can't reload my crossbow. I'm done. Hit ESC to try and quit the game. WHAT- NO QUIT OPTION? No way to quit the game, awesome. What a great game. CTRL+SHIFT+ESC. Cool, already played more than two hours. Not getting that money back. SHITE GAME DO NOT BUY

Update: So I also tried "With Fire and Sword", which is basically the exact same game, except it tells you how to play for once. Have to say, that still did not make me enjoy this game. The game basically punishes you HARD for any single mistake. You have to play PERFECTLY if you don't want to have to start all over again.  Forget to feed your army? Sucks to be you, more than half of them leave your service. Don't even try to fight them to assert your dominance - you WILL be outnumbered. Took a wrong step and blinked once? Get attacked by a vastly more powerful army than yours, and get obliterated. Not nearly enough ways to make money, and your army demands a huge chunk of your savings, so get ready to be in poverty and stuck in the "early game" loop for 12 hours straight, wondering just what you are even doing with your life.  If you're an autistic masochist, then I highly recommend this game. You'll love it. But if you're like me and want to have FUCKING FUN playing a game that doesn't feel like a full time, dead end job with no promotions - steer clear of this garbage.

I enjoyed the combat for the longest time, as well as the commanding controls (wish it was a bit better like with a height map or anything for better placement), but always took a few weeks or months' worth of breaks after a bit. It wasn't until my greatest battle that I was truly hooked on the game, and my breaks were greatly reduced, which I will share as a key reason why I enjoy this game more than Bannerlord.

Using a simple trick in the config file, you can set the max units in battle to 1000, so 1000 soldiers will be on the field at most; that is where I found myself, all 36 of my Swadian Knights, a mix of 38 archers (being trained to sharpshooters) and about 7 infantry (footmen) and 2 companions, a mere 81 men VS the Sultanate horde of 726 (300 fresh recruits and a mix of more capable fighters with about 120 higher tier units). 

Had they continued to update the game like they planned a few years back (I saw a thread to a 64-bit beta version you could test for a time), then I could have had better performance than the 7-12 frames I had, but still the battle was great as my actions were restricted during my charge, requiring me to plan troop movements beforehand. About 230 died before the enemies Calvary came around and started attacking my archers (about 4 died and 2 were knocked out before the frame rate dropped to 4-7 from my turning the view), and I had to retreat... lost about 12 more due to the RNG from withdrawing. The second battle was far better, at about 17-21 fps, so I managed to continue fighting for several minutes before my force was exhausted; by then, having lost 21 more men, I had to fall back for the second time. By the third and final battle, there were little more than 300 vs my ~40 soldiers (about 16 of which were cavalry). The battle was the longest, as their remaining soldiers were mostly higher tier soldiers, and about 70 fresh recruits, and my frame rate was within a playable 30-45 average. The close calls and focus that went into that battle, even having to regroup my knights into a new charging line at the right time and distance to begin a new charge. It is hard to recall, and I wish I was able to record it and not just take a screenshot, but it was my greatest victory (The second battle in my one person war on the Sultanate which resulted in their proposed peace treaty). The battle took about 40 minutes (probably misremembering), which is likely due to the retreating from fps (would be better if the 32-bit game could use more than the 4gb of ram), as it took about 20 minutes for the final battle. Lost over half my soldiers by the end, but was able to replenish most from the prisoner reserves the enemy had.

That battle is usually the first battle I tell new players, as I usually can make it sound cooler and help a someone get into the game; for now, I am just trying to leave a positive review I thought I already left, so figured I would share my battle here. Likely I will start recording my battles if I play it as much as I once did, but I figure I will only do that if they picked up the 64-bit development from where they left off and brought it to steam (It was fully functional, as Mac required both 32-bit and 64-bit versions of the game to be published on their store, so it had a lot of work done while they were working on Mac and Windows version already, and I am sure its still backed up somewhere).
Still better than Bannerloard-shit.

Start small, build up your fighting skills and other abilities, build an army, and take over the medieval lands. The world has a lot of character between the different regions and styles of armies, from cavalry hordes to dense footsoldier armies. There is an RTS element with positioning and managing your squads of different unit types, but unlike most RTS you are riding around and fighting at the same time, like an FPS. Multiplayer is not so fun to me but the single player held my attention for awhile.

Started the Viking conquest reforged edition DLC instead of the main game (by mistake). I still haven't played the main game so the review is basically for Viking Conquest.

It has a story line after completing which can still continue playing the game (to conquer the kingdoms). The story is simple but would force you to level up and build armies to succeed. 

Ever since playing Kingdom Come Deliverance, I was looking for games where you have to a) level up skills, and b) learn to fight with a sword. This game ticked both boxes (although getting better at fighting is much easier in this game).

The game is not perfect. It did crash a number of times for me. But I save frequently anyway, so it didn't impact me much.

It lacks proper guidance on how to build armies / level up. I was expecting some forced quests in the beginning. Could be because it is a DLC and assumes I already know. 
However, in a way, I enjoyed this. I learned at my own pace through experiencing things. May be took me longer this way, but I liked it. In a way, it offered true freedom to go your own way.

If you get lost on how to progress and feel like quitting, you could always watch a video guide. I only watched one once I already finished the main story line (~200 hours) to get better idea on starting my own kingdom (youtube video guide by "Hit Point Inn Gaming").

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game.

Caution: be careful how you use your attribute & skill points. It gets harder and harder to level up.

After having just finished my first playthrough after 100 hours of gameplay I can certainly say I am breath taken and this has easily become one of my favourite games of all time. I've also only scratched the surface as this being a sandbox game has modded variations that take place in Star Wars, medieval times, and the ancient world. I have yet to play these but the base game itself was extremely fun and is so unique. The lore of the game although fairly surface level was extremely interesting and I particularly loved that any person could have any reason to join whatever faction they wanted. It isn't like other games where there's a 'one for all' faction that has the best troops, best cavalry, best archers, etc. They all had their own strengths and weaknesses. I can definitely see myself in the future playing all the other factions. Also just for context, I chose the Nords (Long live King Ragnar). I am also  excited to experiment with different play styles as there's different ways you can play the game, which I won't go into as there's too much to cover. If you've ever wanted to go from rags to riches in a medieval kingdom sandbox with multiple other NPCs and factions all trying to do the same thing, this is definitely the game for you.  Whether it's killing bandits, raiding villages, sieging castles or helping a local lord out in a 3v1 fight, there's plenty of large scale combat to get involved in.

Other interesting and satisfying things to do in the game:
[list]
[*]Recruit a peasant woman in rags with a pitchfork and train her into a sword sister in full plate on horseback with a longsword.
[*]Get headshots from 400+ yards with a bow while mounted by firing into a horde of 40+ clustered infantry.
[*]Use blunt weapons on your troops to knockout enemies and then sell them for fat stacks of coin at nearby cities.
[*]Enter tournaments and win first prize to collect top quality gear and mounts.
[*]Use momentum based damage with a mounted lance to one shot enemies and/or horses.
[*]Get outnumbered, defeated and then captured and have most of your stuff taken.  Then come back with a vengeance and grow even stronger.
[/list]

Hell you can even play as a trader by taking a bit of cash, cramming horses in your party for enhanced carry weight and speed and travel the continent getting rich (buy low, sell high).

In short, game has mounts you can ride and blades you can swing.  Another great game who's title tells the truth:  11/10

[spoiler] Based on my personal playstyle though, I'd call the game Mount & Bow. [/spoiler]

I bought the game solely for the Lord of the Rings mod "The Last Days of the Third Age".
Only 11 hours played and I can already say, this is the best LotR game I´ve ever played.

It´s slow in the beginning, but when the War of the Ring starts, you will wish you had more time to prepare. It does a great job of conveying the feel of urge as soon as the drums of war are heard across Middle Earth. Gandalf said it the best: "Three hundred lives of men I have walked this earth and now I have no time."

The immersiveness, intensity and large scale of the late game of the Mount & Blade gameplay, coupled with a faithful recreation of Rhovanion, Rohan, Gondor and Mordor with it´s cities and fortresses, all while the LotR soundtrack in the background gives you goosebumps, is an experience I have honestly never experienced before.

Put on the LotR soundtrack in the background (because it´s not part of the mod, I guess copyright and stuff) and you will feel like you are taking part in the biggest war of our age, where the fate of the world will be decided on the battlefield of Middle Earth. You play a critical role in preserving the good in the world and rallying as many men around you as you can. However, should you and the strenght of the men of the west fail, then the world will be plunged into a second Dark Age. And it will, because the forces of evil are many.

Visit all the famous places from the Books and Movies, meet all of your favourite characters, join Theoden, Thranduil, Faramir, and many others to defend their lands from the forces of the Dark Lord and purge Moria, Isengard, Gundabad and other key strongholds from those dreadful and hideous Orcs, so that the free kingdoms may unite under your command and carry the war deep into the Black Land, to Barad-Dur, where you are destined to defeat the armies of Sauron on the hillside of Mount Doom.

Or fail and watch powerless, robbed of your destiny, as the shadow of Mordor spreads and devours the regions of the Westland, plunging the last days of the Third Age into relentless and eternal darkness.

If you, however, succumb to the will of the One Ring, you can be the very reason why the destiny of the Last High King fails and Barad-Dur continues to stand strong, bringing death and darkness over Middle Earth.

May the power of the Valar guide you on your way and protect you from the might of the Dark Lord, for the forces of good shall reign supreme, one last time.

This is the best wargame I've ever played.  The combat is tough to master but rewards timing and skill. The ceiling is infinite. The single-player game is a sandbox RPG that is great on its own and there are many mods that can extend the game forever.

The multiplayer provides the most entertaining and challenging fighting I've ever found. The MP community is still hanging on in 2023. Someday someone will make a better one.

warband exists solely so that you can have fun, and everything the game has to offer can be experienced on a single run or you can play through it 100 different times and still have a blast. every time is different, seemingly no matter where you are or what you do, and the game constantly encourages you to do wacky things. make a party that consists entirely of overpowered companions, spend the entire game as a vassal, make an independent empire, do a pure solo game, the list goes on. of course, youre going to start off without the slightest clue what to do, likely make an oversized party that eats up all your funds, and zoom all over the map and get consistently accosted by bandits. the only way to go forward is to learn from your mistakes. maybe you lost a battle because you didnt have enough archers, maybe your entire party disbanded because you didnt have enough funds or set up enough workshops. assess the situation, fix your problems, and wherever that leaves you, just continue on. do what you know, and expand outward. this game is all about progress, and the sooner you realize that, the quicker you will ascend.

First heard of the game from a "Gangs of Glasgow" mod video... bought it cheap to play mods and figured I'd best do one or two vanilla runs to get the fundamentals down first... here I am 270 hours later, still playing vanilla. The vanilla game can be a bit frustrating at times (horrible lord AI, troops are often dumb, politics are a bit shallow) but the combat system is where it shines and generally sets this game apart from other medival RTS titles; with the aim of realism, it incorporates directional attacking, directional blocking and momentum-based damage, and provides a wealth of different weapons and playstyles to chose from. It's also ridiculously satisfying. Easy to learn and hard to master, you'll feel like a wizard if you can get a grasp on melee combat, or you can go the (historically) OP route and just let loose your arrows on horseback.  If you like interesting combat, political manoeuvring and medieval settings, & are generally autistic, then this is the game for you. 10/10, still better than Bannerlord

I have played this game a lot, but I cannot say that I actually like it. I have just closed it in frustration after being given the wonderful quest of driving cattle to my marshal. The wobbliness of the physics of the game was just hard enough to make me fail, but fell short of being fun enough to make me want to try again. Unfortunately, Mount & Blade is full of things like this: they are enticing because you think of how cool it will be to have all those amazing things, but then its physics and gameplay are not interesting enough to make the journey fun. I think the game creators would have to understand that and add a bit more of a rewarding gameplay. For example,  we shouldn`t be given a cattle driving mission by an army that is moving across the map at a faster speed than you`re physically capable of driving the cattle to them. A Lord or Lady surrounded by 50 soldiers wouldn`t be assaulted by 4 brigands at night in a city. And why would the weapon selection system change in that specific situation? And logically manhunters should know where to sell their prisoners, that is not a hard little gift to give your players if you want them to actually have fun and not spend a week looking for a ransom broker at random.

A timeless classic. As good as Bannerlord looks and gets, I don't think ti will be able to scratch the surface of how much of a lightning in a bottle this game is. At its core, it's pretty simple: go from village to village recruiting people, fight bandits to get money, raid villages and castles if that's your style - if not, enroll as a vassal of one of the nations and climb the ranks to becoming king of your own nation. The combat is actually hilarious; it feels like the AI was purposely designed to have the memory of a goldfish and their reactions to being hit/shot and dying drives me insane - even their voicelines are pretty funny!
9/10
To anyone who this strikes a chord with, you should also check out the "early access"-ware sequel, Bannerlord - it is a great follow-up, even if somewhat janky.

I guess I'm the odd man out based on the other reviews, but I stand by my reasoning. 

This game is, at its very core, [i]tedious[/i]. You spend more time running around from village to village than you do actually playing the game. You've got to ensure you've got enough food and gold at all times to keep up moral, and the combat is the very definition of repetitive. Win or lose, you just feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again. 

The free-form sandbox style of the game doesn't help. With absolutely no direction, it's difficult to figure out where the main quests are. Even when you do find them, it's hard to know where to go next, and more importantly, whether or not you're even capable of getting there safely. The sense of progression is lacking, which is very disappointing. 

The music is also kind of ass. It just loops the same 3 different themed songs between combat, exploring and tavern/city. With some very out-dated sound effects (which makes sense since this is an older game, so I'm not holding that against it). Seriously, just play . . any other tactical sandbox. I feel this one is really just a time sink with no real sense of satisfaction.

could replace my meth addiction

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The great thing about this game is that it lets you roleplay as some kind of martial arts-demigod as you go around seeding the fields of whatever in-game universe you choose to play in with the blood and bones of your 'enemies'; some of these guys will be barely-clothed peasants and looters which really give you the feeling of blending cold steel with raw vulnerable flesh as you slice and stab through them, even with your basic starting level of fighting skills and weapon proficiencies and standard issue pig-iron shiv or rusty sword; some of these guys will be knights clad in full plate whom your attacks will just bounce off of without dozens of hours of levelling or upgraded gear first. Some of these guys will be very menacing chads who somehow manage to heave an axe into your forehead from 20 metres away one-shotting you as you eagerly try to kickstart the flesh moshpits which are both a bane and boon of this game, but trust me you'll probably be pretty impressed with this if it does happen.
Now I know different mods have different parameters and ways of dealing with damage and armor points. I usually play the ACOK mod because I'm a fan of the asoiaf universe, and most of the stuff above is more relevant to that. In native I believe the highest-tier armor is actually comparatively less protective than in ACOK, so you will still be able to damage knights even in the beginning. 
There are several combat playstyles you can develop your player character around. I guess the most straightforward one would be to aspire towards becoming a knight-like creature on a warhorse, both of you encased in steel plate, shield in one hand and sword in the other in a perfect balance of offense and defense. Personally I've had fun with a more lightly armored agility and athletics focused character armed with just a long(ish) spear, you can really outrun and outmaneouvre and outreach most heavy goons this way, and have fun poking away at them while remaining flighty at a just-out-of-reach distance. Of course this does leave you vulnerable to arrows and getting mogged by horse guys. 
Also you can just be a horse archer, this is like the warband equivalent of skyrim's stealth archer, once you get to a good level you can one shot or two shot most guys while riding around to get them from an exposed angle, and shooting down the horses of any one chasing you.
The combat is really fun once you get the hang of the basic skills. I'm pretty sure there are a lot of nuances and intricacies hiding beneath something that looks simple at first glance. Feinting, chambering, kicking all exist and can be employed even against bots. One thing that seems to be more dynamic and flexible is weapon matchups actually, since each weapon has its own range and swing speed, when you combine this with the weapon proficiency rating of the character, direction of attack, rotational delay/acceleration done by moving the camera against/together with the direction of the swing, and the actual bodily mobility of each of the two combatants, you can create some interesting situations especially in multiplayer (admittedly I haven't played much of this though). You could, say, end up with a situation where one guy can relentlessly close in and rabidly swing without much concern for blocking at all because the other guy's weapon is so slow that he wont even be able to manage a counterattack even if he successfully blocks each swing because by the time that happens the next swing is already coming again. Alternatively taking off all your clothes and equipping a greatsword longer than your opponents weapon means you can really deploy the juke and flail and kite tactic to its fuller potential.

Multiplayer is pretty crazy and I wish it were more active than it is.

After a short period of playing , I can see that the Forums from Bannerlord were correct.  If you missed this game, it is worth a try even though it came out before Bannerlord.  I read about this game so much in the Bannerlord forums that it made me curious enough to try it.  In just a couple hours I can already see I made a good choice.  I played Bannerlord for well over a thousand hours.  Mount and Blade warband is similar but has its own flavors and details. One of the reasons I got the Bundle was because I enjoyed the content from the other game , and read how much This one inspired that one.  I had to play it.   I just started, And I can see that the forums were correct, this game is cool too.

   And the Viking Conquest dlc is so cool.  I have been playing this dlc for hundreds of hours.  I am really impressed with this Viking Conquest expansion.  I can see why the game and dlcs got so much praise in the Bannerlord forums.  Viking Conquest is a whole game on its own basically it has so much content.  I would argue it is comparable to Bannerlord because you can sail.  Don't get me wrong Bannerlord is worth it, but so is this if you really like war games that are well made.

The Viking Conquest DLC is basically a whole game.  I do not know why it does not get more advertisement, because it is really , really good.  Huge map,  Tons of bad guys to kill, lots of intrigue if that's your thing.  Tons of killing enemies in battlefield settings.  The reputation and renown mechanics are pretty good.

This game + mods = one of the most unique experiences for gaming I've had in sometime. It's pretty straight forward and easy to pick up in concept, but the amount of options and paths you can take leaves a lot of room for replayability. I treat it like a real time strategy board game of sorts where I create a character to play out an RPG lifestyle, recruit an army of followers, and eventually conquer kingdoms, or help other NPCs do the same. Battles play out somewhat like a total war game, except you play as that single general fighting alongside your unit while issuing commands to your troops. I've sank way too many hours into this game (mostly in the Perisno mod) so I'd obviously recommend it, but if this seems like a game you may be interested in, it has been a gem.

Mount & Blade: Warband is a medieval warfare simulation game that allows players to immerse themselves in the Middle Ages. It is a sequel to the original Mount & Blade game, released in 2008, and features significant improvements in graphics, AI, and gameplay mechanics.

Gameplay

The game's core gameplay revolves around battles between armies, which can be either scripted or sandbox-style free-roam. Players can choose to play as a lord, vassal, or mercenary, each with their own unique advantages and disadvantages. As a lord, players have the ability to recruit troops, build castles, and manage their own fiefdoms. As a vassal, players can pledge their allegiance to a lord and gain access to resources and protection. As a mercenary, players can take on contracts for various factions and earn money for their services.

Combat in the game is fast-paced and intense, with realistic swordplay mechanics that require skill and strategy to master. Players can choose from a variety of weapons and armor, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. The game's AI system is also highly advanced, allowing for realistic troop movements and tactics.

Graphics

Warband's graphics are significantly improved from the original Mount & Blade game, with more detailed environments, characters, and weapons. The game's engine supports high-resolution textures and dynamic lighting, creating a more immersive experience for players.

Modding

One of the most popular aspects of Mount & Blade: Warband is its modding community. The game's open-source engine allows for extensive customization of the game's content, including new factions, weapons, maps, and campaigns. This has led to the creation of a vast library of mods that can be downloaded and installed by players.

Conclusion

Overall, Mount & Blade: Warband is an exceptional medieval warfare simulation game that offers hours of immersive gameplay with its realistic combat mechanics, advanced AI system, and extensive modding community. Its improved graphics and sandbox-style free-roam gameplay make it an excellent choice for fans of medieval history and strategy games alike.

ATTENTION HARDCORE GAMERS: Want a real nice fantasy twist on the original Mount and Blade? Spells! Undead! Drow! Clerics! LLoth! Dwarves! Skeletal horse mounts! and so much more...

I sincerely and _highly_ recommend the 'Phantasy 2018' mod (it's not in the workshop that I could find but is on moddb or nexus or whatever). Search YouTube (if you want more details for 'phantasy 2018 than this meager article).


For a brief example here's my initial personal noob experience playing as a Drow focused army: 

Squads of Drow wizards hurling magic missiles, fireballs, globes of darkness, fear effect, acid arrows and more into the enemy ranks while the squad of clerics spams heals and blessings keeping casualties at zero plus adding buffs and debuff negations. The enemy melees close to my front line and I release a horde of orcish warrior fodder mixed with Drow melee elites upon the aggressors as the ranged units continue pelting the enemy with all kinds of means like crossbows, bows, and _magic_ (charm, ice storms, lightning etc.). 

And I've only played this for a few hours so far, I wonder what elese there is find in this top-notch mod...

Phantasy 2018 is a rebuild of the original 'Phantasy Calradia' (2014) and let me tell you there's some action to be had here for a different flavor than vanilla to keep things fresh. While the graphics are a little dated (personally I think they're great, (been gaiming since the early 80s)) the game-play is absolutely timeless. When swords, pikes, and arrows start getting a little stale, here's a way to add some very interesting elements to everything because hell, an army of casters, healers, fighters, and more working in unison makes for a very interesting e-sport experience worthy of an epic Klingon ballad.

So a special thanks to all the modders involved over the years and of course to the original devs that made this epic game in the first place. This is a special game that stands out from others quite clearly and to be honest, I like it better than Bannerlord because of all the mods that are available. There are so many overhauls turning 1 game into hundreds making replayability a major feature of this title even beyond the enthralling game-play.

There's some serious 'bang for the buck' to be had here. This is how games are supposed to be made. 9/10

It's very unique and the multiplayer is great, plus it has a huge mod cummunity allowing for a great degree of replayability. 

First thing you should know is this was probably the first series of games to reintroduce directional combat in modern pc gaming. Nowadays you got stuff like Chivalry or For Honour that do the same thing but back then it was a novelty. This might not be for everyone and takes some getting used to.

The campaing is only playble in singleplayer and is a blast, but does take some learning. You can start your character as a commoner or impoverished noble and venture forth in Calradia in hopes of being granted fiefdoms, or if you really have a lot of free time, uniting the disjointed potentates of the fallen empire.
It boasts probably the best market simulation in any video game including Runescape. Goods are produced in villages and towns, They are delivered by caravans and the supply in the markets is impacted by factors like how many villages have been pillaged and caravans assaulted. Tip, specially proffitable is the iron trade, Additionaly you can start businesses in towns to produce goods which will be in turn sold at the market price which might not allways turn in a proffit. It is interesting you don't even need to interact much with this part of the game, you will make enough money from looting and seeling the pillage anyways, or later from taxes from your demesne.
You notice some of the features in the game were afterthoughts but it is still nice to have them, specially given the time it came out. You can chose your own banner for example and then all your troops and settlements(Except villages) will have that flag hoisted. You can marry and make an alliance, you can solve repetitive quests for random nobles for fame and gold as well as increasing your standing in a given realm.

ahhh Warband. An absolute classic, featuring a combat system which is both intuitive and also has a surprising amount of depth, a lovely big skill page to invest points into, and a massive sandbox world for you to explore, exploit and conquer.

Although its age does show in some places - a few bugs and spelling mistakes, quests which are unclear how to complete, and some balance issues. These flaws in no way overshadow what is excellent core gameplay. And, due to the games age, there are many great mods which not only fix these issues but also add new troops, weapons and armour amongst other things.

There is also the mod category of 'total conversion', these mods completely overhaul the game, such as A World Of Ice And Fire, a GOT themed mod which adds the entire continents of westeros and esteros, all major factions, new troops weapons and armours and so much more.

If you want satisfying combat, a rewarding skill page, and enough mods to keep you entertained for hundreds of hours, then this is the game for you.

If I had to describe this game in one word, it would be “charm”.

-The non-combat music is just so tranquil and evokes a strange melancholic feeling.
-The AI is janky and flawed, but it is pretty funny seeing enemy lords march back and forth while you siege their castle as if they are indecisive about whether to engage you or not.
-The wide variety of companions, with their likes and dislikes. Every player will have their preferred combination of companions, since you cannot viably use all of them at once.
-The graphics are outdated, sure. But again, this ties back to charm. There is visual clarity and you have room left for the imagination.
-The wide variety of builds with the RPG mechanics. You even have control over the stats of your companions.
-You could use strategy, or well, I mean, read any other review and you’ll see “F1+F3” (Charge!!!), You should at least put your archers on a hill behind infantry and then use cavalry to attack behind the enemy or something, but hey, you do you. But this game lets you get away with some really cheesy stuff, and that's part of the fun. 
-And most importantly, the ability to create your own story. Who needs an objective when you can make your own? The feeling of working your way up from a nobody is unmatched. And there is a certain sense of indirect urgency in knowing that the AI will continue to fight each other with or without your interference. Don’t want that faction to get too overpowered cause they are going to be your enemy? Well, you better fight them while you still have a good chance! Want to trade goods between towns and focus on just profit? You can do that too.

There are also a ton of mods, but I found so much value even out just the base game alone.

Dear Mount and Blade: Warband,

  I have played you for over 2,500 hours. In that time, we have experienced so much together. We have fought together, traded together, built kingdoms together, and fallen together. I had so much fun with you, so much anger, so much disappointment, but I have never given up on you. 

When I first played you, I was excited to explore that magical world. I would carve my own path in the dark and unforgiving world of the Middle Ages. I was defeated in my first battle, my first trade venture failed, but I didn't give up. I tried again and again, and eventually I succeeded.

We fought together. We fought against enemy armies, besieged castles, and toppled kingdoms. We traded together. We bought and sold goods, and made a profit. We built kingdoms together. We created our own kingdom, expanded our territory, and spread our fame. We fell together. We fought our enemies, were defeated, and were taken prisoner.

But we always came back to each other. I always wanted to play you, I always wanted to be with you. You were more than a game to me. You were a friend, a confidant, a lover.

Thanks to you, I have met people from different cultures and countries. We fought together, laughed together, and learned together. These friendships will last a lifetime. 

Every moment I have spent with you is a memory to me. I will never forget you.

Sincerely,

-Maximus 🦅

Chao, my fellow fry enthusiasts! Today, I, your trusty fries game critic, am here to share my crunchy thoughts on the timeless classic, "Mount & Blade: Warband." Just like a perfectly golden fry, this game has stood the test of time and continues to be a hearty treat for strategy lovers.

Let's start with the visual seasoning – Warband may not be the flashiest fry in the basket, but it has a rustic charm that's as comforting as a batch of homemade tater tots. The graphics may not be truffle-infused, but they serve their purpose well, immersing you in a medieval world where the clash of steel is as familiar as the sound of sizzling spuds.

Now, onto the gameplay – the heart and soul of any game, much like salt is to our beloved fries. Warband serves up a feast of epic battles and strategic conquests that are as satisfying as perfectly seasoned curly fries. The combat system is straightforward but requires a delicate touch, much like achieving the perfect crispiness in your fries. Whether you're leading a cavalry charge or commanding your troops in a siege, the game offers a spud-tacular blend of action and strategy.

The freedom to carve your path through the potato fields of Calradia is where Warband truly shines. Much like choosing your favorite dipping sauce for fries, the game lets you decide your destiny – be it a noble lord, a roving mercenary, or a potato farmer turned warrior. The sandbox nature of the game gives you the freedom to shape your adventure, just like choosing between curly, shoestring, or wedges.

The soundtrack, like the seasoning on a seasoned fry, enhances the overall experience. The medieval tunes set the mood for epic battles and diplomatic spud-negotiations, adding a layer of flavor to the immersive world of Calradia.

While the visuals and mechanics might feel a bit dated, much like a classic shoestring fry, Warband's charm lies in its simplicity and depth. The game has a timeless quality that, much like a well-seasoned fry, keeps you coming back for more.

In conclusion, Mount & Blade: Warband may not have the glitz and glamour of a gourmet fry, but its strategic depth, immersive world, and freedom of choice make it a classic that's as satisfying as a plate of your favorite fries. So, grab your spud-shaped sword, lead your army into battle, and relish in the enduring delight that is Mount & Blade: Warband. Fry-tastic! 🍟✨

[spoiler]Hello Calradia![/spoiler].

[b]Симулятор товарища майора.[/b]

Захватывать территории не сложно. В метабилде проще, но можно и просто гриндом. Но чтобы их удержать - на территории надо ставить вассалов.
Если вассал не дурачок, то он копит войска, тренирует их, не кошмарит работяг и патрулирует свои территории, ломая лица рванине, которая атакует караваны. Если вассал дурачок, то вассал кошмарит своих работяг, набирает в войска рванину, сам атакует караваны и огрызается на соседей. Дурачок вассал или нет - зависит от [i]характера[/i] NPC.

Список [i]благородных[/i] NPC от игры к игре не меняется, но в каждой новой игре игра случайно раздаёт характеры неписям. Поэтому для эффективного достижения конечной цели, военного объединения всей карты в одно государство, нужно не столько качать персонажа, сколько по максимуму взаимодействовать с неписями. Зачем? Чтобы выяснить их характер и навести дружбу с теми, кто будет вассалом-недурачком.

Поэтому с самого начала игры [b]все[/b] именные NPC должны быть у вас на карандаше. Каждый лорд должен быть постоянно на карандаше. Особенно если вы задумаете женить/замужить ГГ. Нужно понимать, с кем роднитесь и с кем они "в разладе". Потому что породниться с толпой отбитых, которые огрызаются на всех без разбора - это катастрофически хуже, чем прокачать навыки ГГ как попало. Ставить вассалов на земли тоже желательно аккуратно, потому что если соседи будут враждовать - задолбаетесь их мирить. Это не сложно, это нужно их найти и уболтать, а это долго. Поэтому бОльшая часть игры - это разговоры с ноблями, с целью выяснить их характеры, их взаимные отношения и всё писать в книжечку. В книжечку, на карандаш. И делать им одолжения, чтобы крепко сдружиться с недурачками и их семьями.

В игре нет никакого внутреннего журнала взаимодействий ГГ с ноблями, равно как и внутриигровой записной книжки, поэтому детали игрок пишет где-нибудь ещё. Сам.

Как настоящий майор.

Майор, который станет императором. Если будет аккуратно вести личные дела вассалов, конечно.

Mount & Blade: Warband - A Medieval Epic of Strategy and Freedom

[Introduction]

Mount & Blade: Warband is a medieval action role-playing game developed by TaleWorlds Entertainment and released in 2010. The game offers a unique open-world experience and immerses players in a medieval world.

[Story]

Warband allows players to shape their destinies in a medieval world. Players create their characters and then carve their own paths through the wars and trade of different kingdoms. The main story is one that players create for themselves, so personalized narratives develop based on individual player experiences.

[Gameplay]

The gameplay of Mount & Blade: Warband revolves heavily around combat and strategy. Players can engage in various battles either on horseback or on foot. Strategic thinking, tactical planning, and team management are core elements of the game. Additionally, players can get involved in kingdom relations, diplomacy, and trade. The game lets players feel like they are living as a character in a medieval world.

[Graphics and Sounds]

While the graphics of Mount & Blade: Warband may not meet contemporary standards, they effectively create an immersive atmosphere. The medieval world, with its castles, villages, and characters, is portrayed in detail. The graphics work in harmony with the game's depth and atmosphere. The game's sounds are an essential part of the experience, enhancing the atmosphere. Appropriate sound effects and music are used to reflect the medieval setting. The sounds of battle, the silence of castles, and the liveliness of trade contribute to players feeling more immersed in the world.

[Conclusion]

Mount & Blade: Warband was released in 2010 and has gained a large player base over time, with expansions and mods providing continued support. The game's success can be attributed to its open-world freedom, strategic depth, and customizable story options.

In conclusion, Mount & Blade: Warband is an immersive game known for its medieval atmosphere and open-ended gameplay. It allows players to craft their own stories and engage in epic battles, making it highly replayable.

Mount & Blade: Warband Review

Audio: 9/10 - pretty good soundtrack

Balance: 7/10 - mostly fine but very late-game is pretty difficult

Design: 7/10 - pretty easy to understand but some features and mechanics could be better explained in game

Fun: 10/10 - wars, sieges, raids, battles, what more can be said?

Gameplay: 9/10 - good blend of strategic map conquest and first-person battles

Graphics: 6/10 - pretty old and outdated now, but impressive for the time

Extras: 10/10 - extensive modpacks (specifically Floris) make this game worth playing years after its release

Playtime: 9/10 - long playtime, but you might want to try this game’s sequel, Bannerlord, eventually

Stability: 9/10 - no major issues

Story: 6/10 - would be nice if there was better developed lore and story, but it's not necessary

Total: 82 sea raider’s skull cups out of 100

Huh, turns out I never reviewed this game. Basically it's amazing, the core game is made of solid fundations (though the graphics are admittedly dated even by 2010 standards) with a fun core gameplay loop that was then built upon by countless mods. From small balance tweaks to full-blown recreations of historical conflicts to complete fantasy overhauls (including universes such as LotR, Warhammer Fantasy and even some original fantasy settings), there's something for everyone.

I still enjoy going back to this once in a while to replay a campaign or two, as Bannerlord's mods are not anywhere near as complete as Warband ones at the moment, even if the core game is obviously better in almost every aspect, especially siege battles. (then again, at least Warband's siege battles are better than the ones in CA's Total War games !)

M&B: Warband: ITS ALMOST HARVESTING SEASON.

AWAY WITH YOU, VILE BEGGAR!

Now that we're all vaguely forgetting that Bannerlord existed, in the same way I vaguely forget what day it is, we're all coming back to Papa Warband. A game that looks like a potato, plays like utter trash but achieves the right approach to the "open world" gameplay that so many have tried to do without succeeding. It's one thing to be an "open world" game that strings you along a singular story and let you choose what you want to do. Then there's Warband that tells you nothing except the basics of fighting before kicking you out into the world with 3.50 in denars, five random Swadian villagers who just vaguely follow your orders and lets you figure the rest out.

You are some random goon who gets thrown into the medieval world of Calradia, a once unified continent now in the midst of classic old world squabbling. You must decide which of the factions you want to "work" with, which mainly devolves into either following along with your other lords and justifying spending another war having YET ANOTHER FEAST while the Khan takes your towns, burning down 55% of the Kingdom of Rhodoks and selling their generals to Ransom Brokers or enforcing 100% tariffs on random trade caravans until the Sultan call a fatwa on you for stealing all of his paprika. All the while slowly erecting the basic framework of your own military industrial complex based entirely on breweries and weavers built in random towns. To fund your mercenary machine.

Does this game have flaws? Of course. The menu system is a great and terrible reminder that this game is now old enough to have graduated high school and be making mistakes in college, and in lieu of a tutorial this game maintains one of the most in-depth note sections I've ever seen. That being said, the basic frame work of Warband is terribly effective. And even more so in the modding scene. You can add mods that turn this from Sengoku Jidai Japan to Star Wars to WWI and this game chugs along like nothing happens. My personal favorite is still the cowboy mod, solely because you break the game the very second you acquire a Henry rifle.

Warband is scuffed, old, creaking and cantankerous, but it is still one of the most engrossing games I've ever played. I can lose hours to this thing solely because I enjoy running around the world pummeling the snot out of random looters and selling them into servitude. And making fat stacks with stolen goods. Buy it now, if you somehow haven't.

Mount & Blade: Warband is essentially a giant sandbox in which to make your own adventure.  There is little or no hand-holding or even a main quest to follow.  You start out with nothing and build up a band of warriors to take into battle, expand your realm and take on some of the bigger challenges in the game.

If this is your cup of tea, you'll have a blast with this game.  Personally, I love a story to follow, so I didn't get as deep into this game as others in my library, but I had a fun 30 or so hours with it.  Recommended!

[h2]The definitive feudal army battle single player rpg[/h2]
The primal screams of battle and victory your npcs make elevate this already great game to the status of perfection. 

This is one of the greatest rpgs I've ever played in the same league of excellence as og Pokemon and Skyrim with such a uniquely fun system that makes me wonder at the possibilities for other games. Building up your character and squads, commanding units from the front line in a great combat engine and maneuvering the politics and war strategies to build money and power has an endlessly addicting and rewarding gameplay once you start to learn the intricacies and possibilities. 

[b] The Combat[/b] The directional blocking, chambering and momentum based damage bonuses among other subtle mechanics make the combat really deep and fun but also intuitive. It can be a tough learning curve at first but there are great difficulty and mechanic settings to tweak your experience(If struggling I recommend turning down damage to yourself slightly early on but leaving it normal for your allies and messing with the npc battle set ups in main menu to get the feel for the battles). The feeling of successfully leading a cavalry charge, while placing your infantry/archers properly to defeat a tough army you used to run from, saving your only peasant village in the process, is a satisfaction like no other. 

Sometimes rough around the edges but amazingly crafted at the core, you can tell they really focused on developing the things that mattered and the game accomplishes a very specific and unique kind of gaming experience. I've had a blast and haven't even finished a playthrough or messed with the many awesome looking mods yet. 


-There's a lot of ways to play and progress the brutal sandbox world with little guidance which is part of the fun but I do think its worth checking out a few guides on combat and what not or just reading some basics on the wiki if you want to save a bit of time but isn't necessary.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

I have been an avid gamer for many years, and few games have captivated my attention and imagination like Mount & Blade: Warband. This medieval action RPG is an absolute masterpiece that seamlessly blends strategy, combat, and role-playing elements into a captivating gaming experience. Here's why I believe it deserves a solid 5-star review:

1. Immersive Medieval World: From the moment you step into the fictional continent of Calradia, you're transported to a meticulously crafted medieval world. The landscapes, cities, and castles are beautifully designed, making you feel like a true medieval lord or lady.

2. Open-Ended Gameplay: One of the most remarkable aspects of Mount & Blade: Warband is its open-ended nature. You're free to choose your own path, whether it's becoming a noble, forming your own army, or embarking on a life of banditry. The choices are endless, and every playthrough feels unique.

3. Engaging Combat: The real-time combat system is the heart of this game. Leading your troops into battle is incredibly satisfying, and the controls are easy to learn but difficult to master. Whether you're swinging a sword on horseback or commanding archers from a distance, the combat never gets old.

4. Deep Strategy: Managing your kingdom, forming alliances, and making critical decisions as a ruler adds a layer of strategic depth to the game. Your choices have consequences, and you'll need to think tactically to succeed in the complex political landscape of Calradia.

5. Modding Community: The Mount & Blade community is renowned for its dedication to modding, and the game supports an extensive library of user-created content. Whether you want to explore new worlds or enhance the existing one, the possibilities are endless.

6. Longevity: I've spent countless hours in Calradia, and I still find myself coming back for more. The replay value is astounding, and it's easy to sink hundreds of hours into this game without feeling bored.

7. Multiplayer: The multiplayer mode allows you to test your skills against other players in various game modes, adding even more depth and excitement to an already incredible game.

While Mount & Blade: Warband may not have the most cutting-edge graphics, its gameplay, depth, and replayability more than make up for it. This is a game that rewards patience and strategy, making it an absolute must-play for fans of medieval history, role-playing, and epic battles. Whether you're charging into battle with your knights or plotting your rise to power, Mount & Blade: Warband offers an unforgettable gaming experience that stands the test of time. Medieval gaming enthusiasts, do not miss out on this gem!

Just realised I never left a review for my most played game and decided the time was right to correct this oversight. This game is a magnificent sandbox, if you are looking for deep story and quests, look elsewhere. But if you are looking to make your own adventure, be it trading, bandit hunting, raiding caravans, mercenary work etc; then you should love this. Most of the time you will start out doing a mix of these before joining/creating a kingdom and going on to conquer the land. 

The basic game flow is something like this. You start with little money, very basic equipment and after a little recruiting, a small force of peasants. Then gradually find/buy/loot better equipment, level up, promote your soldiers that survive, recruit companions with skills to fill the gaps in your skill set, give them better equipment and level them up. Interact and work for the different factions, get renown and reputation by winning battles etc.

The base game is definitely worth the price and will keep you interested for at least a couple of full games, the DLC adds to the base game nicely but the real gem here is the modding scene. There are many total conversion mods which have been developed over many years and provide complete experiences of their own. Be it Game of Thrones, Middle Earth, the Witcher or more historical eras such as the Crusades or ancient China there are plenty of mods with hundreds more hours worth of play time. This is the main reason why Warband still has an edge over Bannerlord, the mods for the new title are still in their early stages and it will be years before they can compare to whats on offer here. On sale this game is a must buy for anyone remotely interested and full price it is still great value for money.

[h1]A Medieval Epic of Endless Possibilities[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ★★★★★[/h2]

Mount & Blade: Warband is a timeless classic that has stood the test of time, delivering a medieval sandbox experience like no other. From the moment you step into the chaotic world of Calradia, you're thrust into a dynamic and immersive journey that offers endless possibilities.

The heart of Warband lies in its open-ended gameplay. You're free to choose your path, be it as a valiant knight serving a king, a cunning merchant amassing wealth, or a ruthless warlord conquering kingdoms. The freedom to shape your character's destiny is nothing short of remarkable.

The combat system in Warband is where the game truly shines. Mounted or on foot, battles are epic and visceral, requiring strategy, skill, and mastery of various weapons. The feeling of leading a cavalry charge or expertly landing a headshot with a bow is incredibly satisfying.

As you build your army, you'll engage in large-scale medieval warfare, from siege battles to skirmishes. The thrill of commanding troops in the heat of battle and seeing your banner rise above captured castles is unforgettable.

The modding community for Warband is one of the most active and creative I've encountered. With a plethora of mods available, you can completely overhaul the game, adding new factions, maps, and gameplay mechanics. This extends the game's replayability to nearly endless proportions.

Admittedly, Warband's graphics may not be on par with modern AAA titles, but its gameplay depth more than compensates for any visual shortcomings. And let's not forget the incredible sense of immersion the game creates through its medieval soundtrack and atmospheric world.

In conclusion, Mount & Blade: Warband is a masterpiece of sandbox gaming. It may have been released years ago, but it continues to captivate players with its freedom, combat, and modding possibilities. Whether you're a fan of medieval history, strategy, or just open-world adventures, Warband is an experience that should not be missed. It's a journey that you'll happily embark on again and again.

"Mount & Blade: Warband - A Medieval Epic of Grand Scale"

"Mount & Blade: Warband," developed by TaleWorlds Entertainment, is a medieval action role-playing game that combines grand-scale battles, political intrigue, and open-ended sandbox gameplay. It stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of its unique blend of elements and has spawned a dedicated modding community and a highly anticipated sequel.

Expansive Sandbox World (5/5):
The game's open-ended sandbox world is vast and immersive, featuring a medieval realm where players can carve out their destinies. Whether you aspire to be a noble lord, a mercenary captain, or a bandit king, the world of Calradia is yours to conquer.

Realistic Combat System (5/5):
"Warband" boasts a realistic and satisfying combat system. Players engage in visceral, skill-based melee combat, which requires precise timing, positioning, and strategy. The game captures the chaotic essence of medieval battles, making each encounter thrilling.

Deep Political Intrigue (4/5):
The political landscape of Calradia is a key aspect of the game. Players must navigate the complex web of alliances, rivalries, and betrayals among the various factions. Becoming a vassal, forming your kingdom, or manipulating the political landscape adds depth to the gameplay.

Dynamic Economy and Trade (4/5):
The game features a dynamic economy influenced by supply and demand. Engaging in trade, managing caravans, and investing in enterprises can be profitable, adding an economic layer to your journey.

Comprehensive Character Development (5/5):
Character development is extensive, allowing players to customize their avatars' skills, attributes, and proficiencies. As you progress, your character can become a formidable warrior, a charismatic leader, or a masterful trader, depending on your choices.

Huge Battles (5/5):
"Warband" excels in delivering epic battles. Whether you're leading a band of mercenaries or commanding a large army, the game accommodates massive-scale warfare with hundreds of soldiers on the battlefield.

Modding Community (5/5):
One of the game's greatest strengths is its passionate modding community. Countless mods offer a wide range of experiences, from historical total conversions to fantasy adventures, further extending the game's replayability.

Graphics and Sound (3/5):
While the game's visuals are serviceable, they are not its strong suit. However, the aesthetic charm and functional design compensate for the dated graphics. The sound design, with its medieval-themed music and battle cries, adds to the atmosphere.

Conclusion:
"Mount & Blade: Warband" is an outstanding example of a sandbox role-playing game that offers an unparalleled medieval experience. Its expansive world, deep combat system, political intrigue, and character development provide endless opportunities for adventure. The game's modding community ensures that it remains relevant and constantly evolving. While the graphics may not impress by modern standards, the gameplay's depth and richness more than make up for it. Whether you're leading armies into battle, engaging in political maneuvering, or simply exploring the vast world of Calradia, "Warband" is a timeless classic that has secured its place as a staple in the RPG genre.

Edit: an enlightened individual has got me to reconsider, I think this was a very fun game for me, no need to exaggerate the facts.

I first got this game on the Xbox and spent countless weeks of my life pouring my heart and soul into the game. My first character went to Swadia and was doing decently until he made the mistake of riding towards Reyvadin and got demolished by Sea Raiders. It takes a little while to learn the game but once you do you will see just how easily you will climb your way to the top. Most lords have a few God-tier troops and the rest of their army is slop so if you have even a small army of hardened troops you will stomp anybody in your path. I've defeated groups of three lords with well over 130+ troops simply because 98 of those troops were Spearmen that were easily crushed beneath the hoofs of my Knight's horses. I love the diplomacy in this game and having to gain favor with your fellow lords and even your enemy, hearing what they have to say and developing the world around you. This is yet another game where you feel like you're part of the world instead of the entire world. I have watched Rhodoks take over Sultan territory, I have watched Swadia get dragged into a three-prong war and decimated, I have watched Vaegirs drive deep into Khanate land vice versa. My second character is man of legend and any who oppose him will meet his Sword of War and perish. 

Long live Gorg Turgen, he is the true ruler of Calradia. 

May his son who is riding to wherever Bannerlord takes place prosper as he has.

Also Napoleonic Wars is great but I really wish it had a campaign and damn do the bot battles just kinda suck. The AI just kinda gets stuck on a wall on certain maps so it's just you getting vanished by volley fire as you try to solo the other also equally stuck in their spawn army. 

Over 100/10 and I will hold all my friends hostage and force them to play it.

Had no time for something big, just wanted to play something to pass the afternoon. Now I'm tired because I slept the last days not more than 5 hours a night (a morning?) and just have a few hours to get my work done. And yes, I waste the time left to write an review.

This Game looks so old. It looks so simple. Like Gothic from 2001, for example. But like Gothic, M&B is an awsome game! It is complicated to beginn with, because you dont know what to do, but internet helps.

My tipps for starting:

1. Save Game take part on tournaments and place bets on yourself. If you lose just quit and load again.

2. Swadian Knights are killer. Rodhok have great Archers and Pikeniers. Nords have killer Infantrie. But behold, if you have Troops from enemy kingdoms your moral gets down.

3. for the first weeks, work for a lord as a hired sword. Trading can get you income, but its hard.

4. Start to raid towns from enemy kingdoms. First I thought "Oh no, the poor Townspeople!" but its the only save (though you will get attacked by enemy armys by chance. so QICKSAVE) and easy way to get money at first.

5. when you have enough money buy enterprises in towns. they generate money automaticly. but you can just have one per town. And pay attention to the profit the guildmaster will tell you. Some generate negative income.

6. Become a Vasall and besiege enemy towns. If the King likes you, you get one. If not, good luck.

Yeah and you need to be respected from all other partys so do tasks for the king and the other lords. If you win against an enemy speak to the King, he will pat on your back and his respect towards you rises.

Always go in a battle yourself. with some tactical commands and just the fact you do your stuff  on the battlefield, you can win against armys that are three times yours.

Thats what I learned about the game till now. Hope it will help someone.

I have mixed feelings about this game. I do enjoy it, but due to its current state, I can't in good conscience recommend it. Progression in terms of power accumulation is very slow. Some of the quests such as delivering cattle are painfully awkward and protracted, having to try to guide said cattle to the location but they are destined to go in any direction they like. It would've been so much better to just have them added to the party. The tournament is a joke - "I want to be in the MELEE fight please" "Okay, I'll just randomly give you a weapon, which could be a bow and arrows", combat is rather stiff and stilted, stalling at random times and requiring you to be just the right distance (naturally you'd need to be close with melee weapons, but too close and it starts to bug out); and letting your soldiers fight without you is inadvisable, I've lost more battles than I care to count due to this.

With all this said, you do get the feel for being a medieval warrior making a name for himself and conquering the lands.

An enjoyable game overall, but in dire need of a remaster.

Mount & Blade: Warband is a medieval open world sandbox action RPG with strategy elements. It's set in the fictional land of Calradia with factions that resemble real world nations. The game is non-linear with no set objectives, but a common goal is to conquer the entirety of Calradia. 

The game's strong points are its combat mechanics (featuring directional attacking and blocking), character skill system, and large modding community. The weak points are its low quality graphics and animations, poor quest design, lack of a proper overarching story, as well as general bugs, quirks, and some questionable design decisions. 

I wouldn't recommend spending much time with the vanilla / base game. The mods are where it's at. Here are some of my favorite mods, as well as the most popular ones:

[list]
[*]Diplomacy (adds QoL features without changing much else,  used in other mods)
[*]DiploVexed (vanilla but way less grindy + Diplomacy)
[*]Custom Character Creation (vanilla but with more freedom during character creation)
[*]Floris Evolved ("Mount & Blade: Warband: Enhanced Edition")
[*]Gekokujo (Sengoku era Japan - my personal favorite)

[*]The last Days of the Third Age (Lord of the Rings)
[*]A World of Ice and Fire (Game of Thrones / A Song of Ice and Fire)
[*]Prophecy of Pendor (fantasy)
[*]Star Wars Conquest (Star Wars)
[*]Brytenwalda (dark age British Isles - btw these devs were hired to make the Viking Conquest DLC)
[/list]

PS: [url=https://www.youtube.com/@ReformistTM/playlists]The Reformist[/url] on Youtube has great let's plays of Warband and Warband mods.

[b]Note for Linux users:[/b] Although, the native version works, you'll have better mod compatibility with Proton.

This game is still great even after the release of the sequel, Bannerlord. It has its own merit.

It has an active modding community, and mods that have been upgraded and improved over decades of work by dedicated teams. Many of them could have made money as a game in their own right, but instead the creators brought them to us free with this game. It still boggles my mind that I continue to get sweet upgrades to "The Last Days" mod even in 2023!

Native Warband is also pretty sweet in it's own right. High action, loads of awesome gear, large variety of available troops, the list goes on... If you've never tried it, you should definitely give it a go. The official mods are also pretty good, especially Viking Conquest, which adds a load of realism as well as sea travel and combat. Native and VC are really the best for that take over and become the King/Queen feel.
