Single player review of Viking Conquest:
Pros:
- Great combat system; very enjoyable and intense. Feels realistic and works great during both 1vs1 or 100vs100 encounters.
- Very good trading system. Also feels realistic. You buy wine in one city and sell it in another across the sea for much more. Hundreds of different resources from strategic to luxurious and hundreds of possibilities to find your favourite trading routes.
- Epic battles - being able to give commands to your troops during battle.
- Ability to hire all sorts of troops as well as real companions who you can give horses, equipment.
- A LOT OF POSSIBILITIES. You can expand your warband, conquer villages, cities or kingdoms. You can get your reputation high or low. You can be feared of or hated or loved. You can ride monasteries. Get Fame, Kill Jarls. Buy horses, ships and mansions. There is a lot to do.
- Relations between companions and npcs
- Politics between kingdoms; battles you can join as 3rd party, border incidents, kidnappings, raiding caravans, Wars. Different ways to make two kingdoms hate each other. Everything is there. 

Cons:
- Campaign and plot is almost non existent. Story is poorly written and not interesting. And it is very hard to follow it
- NPCs do stuff randomly out of order and sometimes their actions do not make any sense.
- Difficulty is all over the place. Nothing is balanced. You get encounters with bandits that are super easy and then you get encounter where only you and 2 of your mates raid slavers and there is like 50 of them with the bandit king being able to one shot you on realistic difficulty. I had to lower everything down for this encounter and cheese the game to try to lure them in smaller numbers to win it and it was very painful. I have army of 100 people great warriors. Why my character decides to take only 2 people with him to raid small army of slavers? It does not make any sense. It is like that all the time. The game does not let you chose who you take with you it is always random. The same with tournaments you can get sword, spear or stick. If you get stick you have no chance.
- Too much grind to actually get something expensive. You spend like 10 hours of trading away and travelling between cities to get like 20-30k cash and then one ship costs up to 50k, everything is super expensive and weekly cost to upkeep your troops is very high so this game is a constant grind for money which is tiring after a while when the trading gets really boring
- There is a huge world yes but all the cities, villages, towns and monasteries look exactly the same. New countries look the same. When you visited one you visited them all so sailing away to a new land isnt exciting at all. And it definitely should be. Except for a few special encounters on maps like raiding slavers, fighting huge man or an old hero there isnt much to do in terms of exploring. Exploring is simply boring and slow
- Quests are repeating. Yes random quests given by jarls, village leaders or fort reeves are repeating all the time. So yes how many fort reeves may have got their lute stolen by a guard who now is hiding in some random village? The answer is a lot. How many villages will ask you to train them to fight off bandits? Again quite a few. And so on and so on. It gets repetitive. 
- Huge map - it is very hard to keep track of quests. For example Quest says you have to go to this village Retards Ham and it does not say in which kingdom it is or there is no pointer to click on. You have to manually go to the map and scan through hundred of villages and cities to look for the name. It literally can take like 15 minutes if you are unlucky. The same with people who give you quests. When you finish quest it says go back to Jarl Harlasson or whatever but it does not remind you in what fort he resides or what cities he visit. You have to look for him so I ended up not finishing many quests because of that.
- Graphics are really dated and ugly but this is an old game to it isnt really a con but still with all landscapes looking alike and the same grey cities this game just looks ugly. It could use some more colours to be honest
- After 26hours of playtime I lost interest in the game as all of it felt pointless. You can be jarl and conquer kingdoms but the main character lacks personality and agenda. He is driven by revenge but the plot just gets lost somewhere and you end up grinding for money and expanding your warband without higher goal to achieve. I had this feeling that I lost time on this game

So all in all this is a game definitely worth looking at as it is unique - you may like it. But I cannot recommend it due to all the cons I listed and I do not think it is for me. I also think a lot of people who leave positive reviews (and have 1000s of hours of playtime) do it because of nostalgia (and multiplayer perhaps?). Plus yeah actual fighting gameplay is second to none so that is that too.

In my humble and modest opinion Mount&Blade: Warband is by far one of the most immersive, entertaining and fullfilling medival sandbox action strategy games ever created! Even though I enjoyed 'native' very much i've spent the majority of gametime with the Diplomacy 4.LitDum mod installed. The added features make an already great game even better, and basically adds more opportunities of economical and diplomatic tweaks and twerks aswell as some added weapon and armor upgrades, making an already substantially enjoyable game experience better.

TLDR; Great, yet somewhat challenging blend between balancing economy, raising and maintaing your army, developing and preserving "personal" and political relations, map strategy, battle and siege tactics and plain raw and bloody combat.

Better than the sequel, and unfortunately no other game has gotten close to matching what this game did. Despite its age, people still continue to play this game, with new players trickling in slowly (mostly since this can run on a potato), so I don't see it fully dying for a good while, if ever. Even without multiplayer, the singleplayer is excellent (and unique, with Bannerlord still not living up to it in this aspect), and there are also plenty of mods for you to enjoy. Warband is perhaps the best game of all time, and as far as I can tell there will never be any others that ever succeed the legacy that Warband established. I would highly suggest buying it, if you haven't already.

Played single player native and mods on some rag-tag bootleg pirate version since 2013, from that perspective, game is fun when "creative people" can come up with all the cool skins and overhaul using somewhat of a archaic engine. Regardless, single player isn't what I want to stress on this review, I wanna talk about the multiplayer aspect.

Where should I start... I started late at 2016, at the time all the "Whor3banders" who dwell in GK TDM and TG_Arena are pretty much autistically good at this game already, so as you might have guessed it, I was severely tortured physically and mentally (no cap, those guys are absolutely ruthless). However, something about the gaming mechanics kept me going to reached the 3300 hours (roughly) I have now.

You know what it is? I think it's because the combat mechanics is fundamentally flawed if you factored in the ridiculous ways of feinting, spins, and footwork those aforementioned MAXIMUM AUTISM players have introduced. This is probably the greatest irony I have seen in gaming, a game that was never intended to be "perfect" ended up beating its sequel - Bonerlord in terms of multiplayer close quarter combat. If you played both and have invested ample amount of time in their online TDM servers, you will know of the difference I am stressing.

Gonna sound like a cringy old fool to end this rant: "Off it goes the good ol' days of Warband, just thankful the bastards in GK_TDM cured my autism, but I guess all banquets come to an end" 

Sincerely,

Erika/Witzland/Reichsfuhrun

The game is brutal and takes a ridiculous amount of time to complete. It starts out really fun: you recruit some farmers, fight some bandits, sell equipment, purchase armor, fight in tournaments, upgrade your units. Quite often you will accidentally run into a big army that will devastate all of your progress and you essentially start back from the beginning. Once you get your army up to around 100 units the game becomes pretty stagnate. Once you start your own faction it gets very tedious. Your lords wont conquer as many cities as you want so you have to do most of the work which gets very boring as sieges truly suck. Especially sieges with siege towers where you stand there soaking up arrows for five minutes before the tower finally gets to the walls. The end is not very rewarding and you look back at what you have done and feel like you wasted a bunch of time.
This is an all time classic plain and simple.

Mount & Blade Warband is probably one of the best experiences that exists in terms of a truly massive waste of time sans "Western action RPG," since Diablo 2 at least.  To be honest, its a guilty pleasure of mine, but that doesn't mean its bad by any means.  In fact Mount & Blade is kind of like a premier chef handing you his hat, and letting you into his own private kitchen for a whole day before merely saying, "Have fun, remember to clean up when you're done," before walking out of the room.  That being said, what that terrible analogy kind of means is that its a very experimental, do-whatever-you-want-sort-of experience.  You can fight bandits all day, raid villages, engage in petty squabbles with fellow lords (or ladies), challenge drunks to bar fights, you can play the trade game and invest wisely in local business ventures, or you could just read books while watching the world burn down around you.

Truly there is no better freedom in a game then being able to literally retire and then come back to adventuring as if its quite simply a minor inconvenience.  This sort of freedom to go wherever does have a few caveats of course, you will get into trouble, whether its random dice-rolls of bandits attacking YOU in the city streets, or deserters from local armies asking you for money very impolitely before steam-rolling you with cavalry if you say no, or literally losing a tournament because a stray pixel from a blunt jousting lance struck you for 6 damage due to insane RNG causing you to be eliminated.  Basically most things in Mount & Blade are resolved through conflict, with very little not being resolved by conflict.  So in many ways, the easiest things to do to make money are kind of boring, like hiring a bunch of cavalry and fighting sea raiders ad nauseam till you can afford some decent equipment.  Or fighting sea raiders till your renown is so high every Kingdom within 50 miles wants to hire you ASAP, so you can get a fief that will be instantly raided by the first lord in whichever adjacent kingdom you happen to be at war with.  Politics?  Politics are sort of goofy.  You can bait kingdoms into wars, you can join up with outcasts to reclaim kingdoms, and you can even just do dirty work for one particular lord (in each faction) to cause untold disaster.  My favorite is joining Swadia and causing every single faction to go to war with them at once, which is hilarious.  Swadia sucks, and is typically first on the chopping block as far as elimination is concerned.  Their AI also causes them to often throw tournaments and feasts- even when they're constantly losing castles or cities.

The AI is terrible.  I mean its all pretty funny when a level 0 looter can knock you out with a rock to your face, but they also aren't programmed to adjust tactics quickly enough to avoid getting a sword in the face by a drive-by horse assault.  I would say the worst offenders in terms of clearly getting a handicap are the tundra bandits, forest bandits (who get some crazy two-handed bonus damage resulting in instant K.O.'s on your troops), and steppe bandits who are absolutely terrible in combat, but if they charge you with a lance its lights out.  The horse combat is atrocious, but its the best the engine can do.  Same with sieges, though I understand the idea, its just the way they play out that make them aggravating.  Basically everyone gets bunched together slowly walking up a ladder to get.. instantly killed by archers or elite infantry and its pretty bad.  However, even with all these flaws, the game is never really boring.  If you get bored of something, you can ride somewhere else, start a new army, hire manhunters, go slave hunting and selling.  You can go do combat trials, arena fights, hire various party members to bolster skills you don't have.  If you want the ultimate challenge?  Try playing as a woman in Mount & Blade.  That's literally the hardest difficulty in the game- seriously.

I could on and on about everything in Mount & Blade, but I'll tell you this: I don't even like Action RPG's, but I love Mount & Blade.  Its that good.  So I seriously recommend it, though the combat system takes some time to get used to, after that its pretty smooth sailing.  Just don't pick crossbows.  Just don't.

Are you a fan of RPGs (Role-playing games)? Are you intrigued by the medieval period? And most importantly, do you like riding horses and besieging castles all day long? Then this is the game for you! 

Mount & Blade: Warband is a game released on March 30th, 2010, by the Turkish company ‘TaleWorld’ Entertainment. The game is set on a fictional region of Europe called ‘Calradia’ in the year 1257. The objective of the game is rather simple: rule all of Calradia. You start as a lonely man (or woman) who during your childhood dreamt of being a warrior and a leader of a mercenary warband. To recruit more people to your warband you can either recruit villagers or go to taverns located in cities and recruit more experienced people such as Knights, Paladins, Bandits, Hunters etc. (tends to be more expensive). What needs to be kept in mind is that the more people you have in your warband, the more money you need to have to pay their salary, because if you don’t, then lots of people will start deserting from your group. 

The game has six different factions you can be part of: Kingdom of Swadia, Kingdom of Rhodocks, Kingdom of Nords, Kingdom of Vaegirs, Khergit Kanate and Sarranid Sultanate. When you join a faction, as either a warrior or vassal, you’ll from then on fight for that faction, besieging castles and fighting against vassals from enemy factions. You may also create your own faction, but then ruling Calradia becomes way more difficult. There’s also the possibility to strengthen your relationship with a vassal by marrying someone from his family.

The way economy works in the game is simple. The currency is ‘denars’ and you can earn them in various ways, such as completing tasks delivered to you by vassals, buy a land to manage a mill, you can, after battles, sell the gear from the enemies, or even raid villages. If you conquer a city from another kingdom or conquer back one of yours, and you become the lord of it, you’re able to hire people to manage the economy of the city, the garrison, and the prisoners. 

Overall, my experience with Mount & Blade: Warband was and still is very pleasing. I was pleasantly surprised by how simple this game is. What I liked the most is the combat system. You can choose from how you want your sword to swing to if you want first-person or third person. However, what I disliked the most was the fact that, sometimes AI (Artificial Intelligence) gets stuck in some corners, and I end up losing a lot of troops because of such programming errors. I would certainly recommend you buy the game!

Mount and Blade Warband is a game set in medieval fantasy. You can play it either in 1 person or 3 person and while the graphics are outdated , the gameplay is fantastic, you want to be a mercenary with a small but decent group of warriors , taking contracts for coin? do it. You want to become a vassal in one of the main factions of the game and serve them? say your oath. You want to create your own kingdom and conquer all of Calradia? gather your army. The game has some strategy elements while also providing great combat action, combined with some small realistic elements like wages for troops ,food and some logistics , especially if you like to earn your coin by trading. I recommend Viking DLC since not only it offers just as much as the main game , but also improve it and add a good story campaign as well. When you finished both , the community offers a good selection of mods that greatly add more content for the game and improve it overall. The game is old but offers a lot, so if you enjoy games set in medieval times , add Mount and Blade Warband on your list.

Of all the games I own on steam, I have played this one the most because of the extraordinary amount of diversity in gameplay experiences that its modding has to offer. The modding community for this game is absolutely incredible. I have logged so many hours, spent wandering locations that other games have yet to offer me the freedom to explore. 

From the Third Age of Middle Earth to the Napoleonic Wars, I have so many incredible memories of playing this game:
Forming the lines of Rohirrim and breaking the ranks of Isengard and Mordor,
Reclaiming Moria for the great descendants of mighty Durin,
Becoming Oda Nobunaga's right hand vassal and the most powerful woman in Japan,
Fixing bayonets and charging through volleys of musket fire while standard bearers wave our glorious flag,
Seizing enemy positions and chasing them to fallback lines, while Les Mis blares in my headphones,
And many more. I love this game!

Mount & Blade: Warband remains an epic time sink to this day thanks to its huge scale, endless possibilities, and vibrant modding community. The basic gameplay concept is genius - lead your own medieval army, fight in massive battles, develop your skills as a warrior, and forge your own path in a realm rife with conflict.

There's just so much freedom in how you choose to play. You can follow the main story quests, become a mercenary captain, build your own kingdom from scratch, or just roam the lands as a traveling adventurer for hire. Everything from trading, tournaments, bandit-hunting, and castle sieges are at your fingertips. And as you progress, you really feel your characters grow in power and influence.

But what keeps bringing me back again and again are the amazing mods. I've spent over a hundred hours in mods like A Clash of Kings (based on Game of Thrones), The Last Days (Lord of the Rings), and so many more historical or fantasy-inspired mods. They provide an entirely new campaign and scope for Warband's already addictive gameplay loop.

The A Clash of Kings and The Last Days mods are prime examples of how Warband's modding community has breathed new life into the game. A Clash of Kings transports you to Westeros during the events of the A Song of Ice and Fire novels. You can champion different houses during the ongoing civil war and shape the fate of the Seven Kingdoms. The Last Days mod brings J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle Earth to life, allowing you to fight for Gondor, Rohan, or Mordor during the War of the Ring. With overhauled factions, troops, quests, and environments, these mods feel like entirely new games crafted within Warband's framework.

More broadly, modding has given Warband unprecedented longevity, allowing it to remain relevant and worth playing over a decade later. A constant stream of new mods means there are always fresh campaigns, settings, and historical periods for players to explore. From ancient Rome to the Viking age to steampunk worlds, modders have turned Warband into their own personal sandbox for creativity. The game's mod tools and robust systems make it easy for motivated fans to develop new mods and reshape the gameplay in almost any imaginable way. The result is a level of variety, customization, and "replay value" few games can match even a decade after launch.

Even though Bannerlord improved the engine and graphics, I still come back to Warband thanks to fantastic mods that enrich the core experience, giving me many new characters and stories to immerse myself in. The basic gameplay and sandbox structure are as fun and timeless as ever. If you enjoy open-world RPGs and medieval strategy, Warband without a doubt deserves a spot in your game library.

P.S. The only [i]valid[/i] way to play is to rush a death stack of Swadian Knights... 😛

Wage War, and gather your Band! 🐎

The definition of addiction.

Pros,

I am going to start with the modding community, just incredible and better than the DLC's, even some better than Bannerlord which is a shame.
This game will run on a calculator.
Easy learning curve which isn't too brutal.
Plenty of troop trees, tactics, formations and battles.
A story which allows you to do whatever you wish.
Satisfying combat and character progression.
The option to go from a somebody to a nobody with no forced paths.
Graphically pleasing but only in the sense it makes me feel like I am playing a game from my childhood.
Many battle areas which all bring their own challenges.
An almost Fable like good/evil system where choices you make on day 30 might screw you over on day 300.
Combat that is easy to learn and hard to master.
Ways to make money that don't involve killing everyone and everything.
Sound design that is basic but fills the need it is required for.

Cons,

The game still has some bugs, some which mean resetting long sieges.
The DLC's don't have achievements and are rather pricey.
Native balancing is an issue which shouldn't have been left to modders to fix.
Battle size limited to 150 which is nothing on modern hardware.
The game can be a little grindy when you are conquering the final few factions.
The persuasion system is strange and doesn't always make sense.
The XP curve is crazy for levelling up.
The morale system is somewhat flawed.


Warband is an amazing game, but you truly have to be willing to learn and have patience.

I would recommend buying this before purchasing any of the other games in the series as this game was truly the first time anyone took notice and there is a good reason for it.

Horses are a BIG advantage, except for in sieges and oh yeah there's sieges and they're difficult as hell, I wouldn't recommend getting yourself wrapped up in those until you have the charisma and leadership to lead a huge army. If you are looking for some hardcore medieval simulator, you have come to the right place!

Mount and Blade Warband is a great game, even after many years.

You can create your own hero, edit his or her stats (yes, you can play as a woman), his tactics, bow abilities, long sword abilities, and so on.
 After that, you can choose your own place of origin. You can choose Khergit Khanate, Kingdom of Nords, Sarranid Sultanate, and many others. You can even create your own faction if you have the resources necessary to do so!
 In the early stages of the game, you play as a somewhat poor soldier, businessman, thief of whatever you want to be, later on, you control massive armies with other counts or kings, make thousands of denars or even be the most feared thief, you can choose your own story and gameplay.
 You can battle bandits, villagers, and enemy soldiers or even lay siege on castles and cities.
 Just imagine, battling with other counts and kings against the enemy's hundreds of soldiers, using soldiers, cavalry, terrain, and formations to your advantage. Then having a large battle over some small castle or city that can turn the tide of war. There are many things to do, and you choose what to do.

Graphics are somewhat mid but in some places can be beautiful. If you really want 4k graphics, try looking for some other game or try mods which I will talk about later.

The game is playable even on low-end computers (like mine). I am playing on somewhat high graphics settings and I am getting 60+ fps, even on some big battles. So if you have a low-end pc, it's the right game for you.

The game has a variety of mods, including more variability in editing your character, better graphics, bigger battles of 1000+ units, playing in a fictional world or some even change the game completely, castles, cities, units, kings, terrain, and so on...

If you are still hesitating, get it on sale.

The medieval world of Calradia is in turmoil, and only you can break the deadlock by becoming a lord in one the land's factions. What factions, you ask? 
Vaegirs: Slavs with arguably the most balanced roster in the game
Nords: Viking fanboys who think cavalry are cringe and naturally get stomped on every game
Khergit Khanate: If you didn't like horse archers before, you will surely despise them now
Sarranids: bunch of Arabs who don't do anything particularly well, but their style is on point
Swadians: yes, the generic, overpowered knights faction for you basic b!tches out there
Rhodoks: Pikes, crossbows, and heavy armor. You'll laugh when you fight them in the field; and cry when you try to take one of their castles. 
You: yes, you can make your own faction. Desperately try to carve out you own kingdom, fighting off waves of your rivals' armies, before coming to the terrible realization that your lords will consist of everyone else's sloppy seconds (and odds are, they all hate your guts)

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
My time on the game says it all, just buy it and play.

Almost 15 years old and yet still one of the best medieval RPGs of our time. It's clunky as any other game of the time would be but despite its ugly graphics and simple gameplay it's so easy to get entranced by the in depth politics, world, and story. Not to mention the way the engine is able to simulate these amazing large scale battles it just feels so cool to charge with your troops against an enemy force. Also, the modding scene is fantastic. I want the sequel but I know that it can never replicate the first. It's truly a modern masterpiece and a classic.

If you're fond of Medieval European fantasy with it being grounded a bit more in Earth history and less in Skyrim or Azeroth, this game is certainly not wasted money.
The good:  The atmosphere and tactics of this game take a long time to become tedious.  It's also highly moddable if you're a bit tired of the vanilla version.
The bad: The AI is a bit broken and exploitable, especially during sieges, but I found this took a while to become tedious.  Visuals were dated when it came out, but I found that the action made up for it.

I totally understand why there is so much love for this game, but I just couldn't get into it. So many wonderful ideas and systems, and a really fantastic level of player agency and depth, but too much of it is painfully clunky, buggy, and tedious. I really wanted to lose myself in the sandbox, since there's so much promise here. Unfortunately, I just couldn't get past its shortcomings. 

Note: I hear a lot of the more frustrating issues can be solved with mods and/or .ini-edits, and that may very well be the case. My review is based solely off of a few hours of the vanilla playthrough. As always, YMMV.

Warband is a very dated game: The vanilla battle size (and additionally the maps) are much too small, with a cap of just 150 units. 

Siege battles are tedious and very stupid (what with one ladder access) and the gate can't even be opened. 

The spear, the fundamental melee group weapon, is completely unplayable either on foot or mounted.

Success in battles with lords quickly feels as it becomes: inconsequential. You defeat a Lord in battle, they then likely escape and in 2 weeks they will have another army.

With 100% damage to you and your troops, the need to specialise your character becomes paramount. The exponential decrease in experience gained over time means you realistically need to focus on a INT or CHR build. 

One leads to great surgery and pathfinding stats (but a max army size of around 100), the other provides a bigger army (perhaps around 180), though it's likely you will move too slow to move around the map and you will take a boatload of casualties.

Like all of us, you'll start out alone, with almost nothing in the grand scheme of things.  If you are able to make shrewd decisions, if you are a competent leader, and if you ally yourself with the right people, you may make it past the midgame.  your numbers will swell, and then decide who to swear allegiance to.  play your cards right, and use the lives of your men wisely, and you may even be granted a fiefdom.  

honestly, i dont even know how far the player can go.  can we become a king??  that would be cool, for a long-term goal.

my stories usually end when my king calls me into battle on one of his campaigns.  I try to position my forces in the best place to defend and also stay effective, keeping as many of my allies alive as possible.  usually after my king makes a fool's decision, falling into a trap of armies that double our size,  i'll desperately use what units i have to turn the tides.  more often than not, i get overwhelmed and taken prisoner.  i know that i can keep playing that save, getting hauled around for a bit and eventually let go/ransomed.  thats not really my style.  one shot or nothing.

As a history lover I feel obliged to write this review, altough the game has been released 13 years ago. Starting from the most important aspect of all games- the price- You can buy this game on a sale for like 2$ so it's terribly cheap, and I love that fact.
Game itself provides sufficient amount of content, and many, many ways to play it. The main goal is to create your own kingdom. You can achieve it in many various ways. By starting as a mercenary for another king and eventually become their vassal, being a merchant, or even leading a bandit lifestyle raiding caravans and villages. When you'll save enough coin in your pouch, you can start to build your own, strong army and conquer other realms on your own and become your own, powerful ruler. But let's say the game starts boring you. No problem, there are plenty of modifications that turn this game into completely different level. 
But let's also speak about the disadvantages:
To be honest, the graphics are not breathtaking in 2023, but they'll do. The game still have some minor bugs, but most times you won't even bother about them. The only one really upsetting issue is there are only 9 save slots, so you can't have multiple campaigns with many safety saves at the same time. 
Overall the game is still worth playing despite Bannerlord being available. If you love the feeling of building your own empire, army and managing it, then I recommend giving Warband a try. 
My Personal Rating: 8/10

Mount and Blade: Warband is a medieval action RPG that offers players an immersive and unique gameplay experience. The game takes place in a fictional world based on medieval Europe, where players can create their own character and embark on a journey to become a powerful ruler.

One of the most impressive aspects of Mount and Blade: Warband is its open-world gameplay. The game allows players to explore a vast, dynamic world filled with a wide range of characters, factions, and enemies. Players can engage in various activities such as trading, fighting in battles, sieging castles, and recruiting troops to their army.

The game's combat system is also excellent. The game features a complex and challenging combat system that emphasizes player skill and tactics. Players can use a wide variety of weapons and engage in different types of combat, including mounted combat, archery, and close combat.

Mount and Blade: Warband also offers a deep and engaging character progression system. Players can level up their character and develop their skills and abilities to become a more powerful warrior or leader. The game's diplomacy system is also impressive, allowing players to form alliances, negotiate with other factions, and engage in political maneuvering.

One of the few drawbacks of Mount and Blade: Warband is its graphics, which are somewhat dated. However, the game's graphics are still impressive given the game's age and the complexity of its world and gameplay mechanics.

In summary, Mount and Blade: Warband is a must-play for anyone who enjoys medieval action RPGs. The game offers an immersive and challenging gameplay experience that emphasizes player skill, tactics, and character development. The game's open-world, combat system, and character progression system are all excellent, making Mount and Blade: Warband one of the best RPGs of all time.

Such a good single player experience. You get to have so much control over your character, the actions, and the story. Truly a medieval hack and slash sandbox, where you get to build an army and ride out to battle. Find romance and gain power, lay siege on castles, capture enemy Lords and even Kings (selling them for ransom, or keeping them locked away forever: your choice), even expand your kingdom or wipe another out entirely.. 

Then there are the mods. You can go anywhere with mods, and the mod community is very big. You can add in custom items or story or anything really, guns/muskets even. This game can even be completely reskinned to starwars if you wanted...

If you're a new player, get bannerlord instead. But I'll probably be coming back to play some more PoP 3.9.5 for a long time.

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is the best of all time. I have played many games way more than I have this one but no game has gotten much enjoyment out of me as this one has. There are games that come close but this game remains my number one.

Everything about this game is great. The music, the combat, the modding, the base game, the graphics aren't great but have a charm and somehow I find the ugly graphics beautiful. Walking in a village at night and looking at the sky is amazing. This game has so much freedom and while most people playing this game usually set their main goal as taking all of calradia with your own or another faction, you can be an outlaw who raids villages and attacks caravans, a trader who makes a living by trading your goods with different towns, or you can just take whatever jobs come your way. And with mods, there might be more. I haven't even beaten the game or played the multiplayer which has a loyal and alive community within it keeping the game breathing after 11 or 12 years and I find this game to be the best I have ever played. Now, for modding I would recommend using nexus for most mods but if you are going to use the workshop, you should go for total conversion mods. Speaking of which, the mods are amazing. There is a mod that transforms the setting into a star wars setting! How sick is that? And there's a viking dlc which comes with a storyline as well as a napoleonic war (multiplayer only, excluding the custom battles mode) dlc. I haven't played any of that (as well as the many other things I plan on playing) for more than five minutes but I am excited to. This game has a ton of replay value, you can sink thousands of hours into this game and not get bored. I can't remember getting bored playing this game. Learning this game is a challenge at first but you will get the hang of it if you try. The game is a very hard game to play even with the easiest modes/settings. A very harsh world, especially if you are a woman or a stinky peasant.

With all of this, I have to say this is a must-buy. In my opinion this game is a masterpiece, even without mods or the two expansions. Also, if you can't read at all and you rely on voice acting, then learn to read before playing this because the only voices you hear during this game are funny voicelines that you hear by talking to certain npcs and the voicelines have nothing to do with the dialogue but they let you know who you are talking to if you are for some reason playing this while being blind. Farmers say things like "it's almost harvesting season" and "my lord". Bandits say "that's a nice head you have on you shoulders" as well as "you better not be and man hunter" and much more. The voicelines add to the charm and humor of this game.

If this review isn't convincing, you can create funny looking characters.

i played it now for a few hours, and i must say:
This game is:
- still one of the best combat oriented games
- very good mods
- you're not going to get bored of this game easily
- easy to learn , but hard to master, this game
This game is essentially about your
character going from unknown poor adventurer, attracting (wo)men to join
your team(party), and hunting bandits, to becoming a conqueror of lands,
building alliances with powerful lords and rising your rank
on the hierarchy, generating enough wealth to afford armies and

[h1]Speko Review: Mount & Blade[/h1] 

[b]Mount & Blade: Warband[/b] is a medieval action RPG that was released in 2010 and quickly became a cult classic. Developed by TaleWorlds Entertainment, the game is set in the fictional land of Calradia, where players assume the role of a warrior who must rise through the ranks of feudal society, amass a powerful army, and eventually conquer the entire land. The game features a unique blend of real-time battles, character development, and role-playing elements that make it a compelling and immersive experience for fans of the genre.

[u][b]Character Development:[/b][/u]

One of the standout features of Mount & Blade: Warband is the depth of character development that it offers. Players start out as a lowly warrior with little more than a sword and some armor, but as they progress through the game, they can gain experience, level up, and acquire new skills and abilities. The game features a wide range of skills, including archery, horseback riding, swordsmanship, and more, and players can allocate skill points to these areas to customize their character to their playstyle.

[u][b]Real-Time Large Scale Battles:[/b][/u]

Another major highlight of Mount & Blade: Warband is the real-time army battles that it offers. Players can gather troops from various towns and villages throughout Calradia and lead them into battle against other armies, bandits, and other foes. The battles are dynamic and intense, with players able to issue commands to their troops, ride on horseback, and engage in close-quarters combat. The battles feel authentic and are a true test of a player's tactical abilities.

[u][b]RPG Elements:[/b][/u]

Mount & Blade: Warband is also a deep and immersive RPG, with a wide range of quests, factions, and characters to interact with. Players can pledge allegiance to various lords and ladies throughout Calradia, engage in political intrigue and diplomacy, and even get married and start their own kingdom. The game has a nonlinear structure that allows players to pursue their own goals and objectives, whether that be becoming a powerful mercenary, a wealthy trader, or a conquering warlord.

[u][b]Choose Your Own Path:[/b][/u]

One of the most compelling aspects of Mount & Blade: Warband is the sense of freedom that it offers. Players are not restricted by a linear storyline or forced to follow a predetermined path. Instead, they are free to choose their own destiny and pursue their own goals. This sense of agency is a major selling point for the game and is one of the reasons why it has such a dedicated fan base.

[u][b]Modding Community:[/b][/u]

Finally, Mount & Blade: Warband is renowned for its modding community, which has created a vast array of custom content for the game. From total conversions that transport the game to other settings, to smaller mods that tweak gameplay mechanics, there is no shortage of user-generated content available for the game. This adds tremendous value and replayability to the game, as players can constantly find new experiences and challenges to tackle.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Deep character development
[*]Dynamic real-time large scale battles
[*]Immersive RPG elements
[*]Nonlinear structure allows for freedom of choice
[*]Modding community adds value and replayability
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Outdated graphics
[*]Steep learning curve for new players
[*]Repetitive gameplay in later stages
[/list]
[u][b]Conclusion:[/b][/u]

Overall, Mount & Blade: Warband is a fantastic game that offers a unique and compelling blend of real-time battles, character development, and role-playing elements. While it may not have the most cutting-edge graphics or the most accessible gameplay, it more than makes up for this with its depth and replayability. With a dedicated modding community constantly adding new content to the game, it is a title that players can enjoy for years to come.

I'm torn whether to recommend this game. It's a good game (I wouldn't have 465 hours if I didn't like it), but it is dated  and there's a new Mount and Blade out.  In fact, most of my early time was spent with Warband, but most recently I've been playing mods such as Prophesy of Pendor and Perisno.

Honestly, the game is basic enough that there's not much I can really say about it other than I usually reach a point at the end where it's just boring - I can beat every army, but trying to track them down to fight them gets tedious.  The Lord system is annoying.  Anyone except good aligned and Upstanding lords complain when you don't give them land, but because of their nature, the good aligned and upstanding lords never abandoned their lords.  Worse, I could never attract them no matter how much land or money or anything I had - they always went to other kingdoms (where they would just get slaughtered again).  

There's not much diversity in troop trees either with Warband only have like three trees for each nation (infantry, archers, and cavlary) and there were clear winners (Swadian Knights).

However, there are lots of mods, some of which try to improve things like more troop variety.  However, they still use the game's engine which again is quite dated.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

With over 1k hours played, on both PC and PS4, I can confidently say that this is the best game I've ever played. While there are other titles that are also excellent, this game takes the cake. I have never had a game that pulls me back for more year after year of game play. Despite the now old looking graphics, its a game that keeps on giving. From Warband to Viking Conquest, the game has forever held a grip on what I love about games. The immense complexity, the love of both first shooter and RPG style gaming and sheer quality/quantity of the game mechanics. 

Now I waited for Bannerlord for what seems like years when they first announced it (I'm not even that big of a geek I just love this game). And when it dropped, it was pretty, it was fun and then... it fell bland. The complexity, the diplomacy, the absolute fun that I had come to love from this game simply just doesn't exist in bannerlord. So, even though I committed 250 hours into that game, I am back here looking to spear a pig in Danmark after a solid monetary sacking and lead a contingent of Vladian knights through the irritating masses of Rhodokean Sharpshooters above a glitching out hill side. 

This game is a piece of art and a legacy that Taleworlds needs to bring back into Bannerlord.

I have way more than 20 hours in this game and its predecessor. I used to play it on disk all the time back when people still bought PC games from brick and mortar stores, it just had a really good sale and convenience is a thing. It's honestly my favorite game of all time. I come back to it again and again because it is just so addicting. A true sandbox where a world is laid before you and your journey is what you make it. Build alliances and shuffle up the political ladder, take up the cause of a claimant to a throne, or just brute force your way across the country and fight for survival. That's not to mention how in depth you can go with controlling your army or all the different ways to make money. Sure it's got dated graphics and the combat mechanics leave a lot to be desired for the modern gamer, but as far as classics go, it's a gem.

Mount & Blade: Warband is a medieval action role-playing game that has been highly praised for its open-world sandbox gameplay and dynamic combat system. Players create their own character and navigate the game world, engaging in battles, building their own kingdom, and participating in quests and diplomacy with other factions.

The game's realistic and challenging combat system, combined with its large and immersive game world, has made it a popular choice among players who enjoy immersive and complex gameplay experiences. The game also has a strong modding community, which has added even more content and features to the game over the years.

Overall, Mount & Blade: Warband is a must-play for anyone who loves medieval-themed games, open-world sandbox games, or action role-playing games. The game offers a unique and enjoyable gameplay experience and is sure to provide countless hours of entertainment. If you're looking for a game that will challenge you and allow you to create your own unique story, give Mount & Blade: Warband a try.

The only reason why Warband's multiplayer worked in the late 2010s is because players around that time had enough honor to not spam archers and render other classes unplayable. Trying to play multiplayer in 2023 onwards will have you eat even more archer spam than you'd find in Bannerlord.

I couldn't get into the singleplayer personally, but I've had a blast with the game's multiplayer mode hence the number of hours i clocked in. Unfortunately, the Warband multiplayer install base in current year is far more interested in squeezing out wins with minimal effort than they are enjoying the game's melee system.

This game owes a lot to its faithful community, as evidenced by a workshop full of various modifications, and constant activity on various multiplayer server modes. I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

What can be said about Warband?  Without a doubt this is one of the finest computer games of all time, even with its sequel out, this old game is still well worth picking up and playing.  Fighting in battles and sieges is still engaging more than a decade on and the awesome range of mods available for this game add a considerable amount of variation and value.  Personal recommendations are Prophecy of Pendor, Perisno and BannerPage.

Hello there, I welcome you in a fantastic adventurer known as Mount&Blade Warband a certain game that doesn't need much introduction but if you lived under the rock or happen to be a ex-fortnut kid. Whelp, here a quick heads up for you.

This game is fairly simply to understand, you make character, you go in the world, do quests, recruit slobs to fight for you, conquer, prepare to nuke the world because you become a force of nature that nobody can stop you, rinse and repeat until you happen to discover the workshop menu or nexus, experience the joy of the extreme fashion statement that is modded Warband.

To put mildly, this game is truly like an addiction of sorts once you get stuck in the endless loop of war, you never stop. You go on and on sinking maybe what could be humanly put 200 hours of gameplay because you simply having nothing better to do.

Then if you are lucky, you get to experience the amazing world of meme posting that is warband, a truly terrific experience to say the least, maybe if I wasn't high on king Harlaus's butter after he hosted the twenty-sixth feast in a row while Swadia is under attack.
Oh, did I forget to mention, it's almost harvesting season my lord.

Now excuse me, I'm going to drink from your skull...
IT'S ALMOST HARVESTING SEASON!

Especially with the modding scene, Warband is probably up there as one of the best games ever made. Nowhere else will you find the freedom to go from lowly mercenary to emperor of Calradia while having to juggle your kingdom's economy, political situation, and your 'friendly' neighbours. 

Is there a grind at the end game? Yes, eventually it gets boring to siege and conquer over and over again just to finish off the map. But Warband is one of those few games where I don't mind taking a palate cleanser and starting a modded playthrough, and STILL finding the vanilla game fun when I come back to it fresh.

Speaking of mods, I whole wholeheartedly recommend Prophesy of Pendor. As far as total conversions go, I think it's the best transition thematically from vanilla and only makes the game better. Also harder. But still better.

Cons: If you're vegan, there's no option to avoid drinking from enemy skulls :(

Now now. The new installment to the franchise finally came aka aka aka (Bannerlord). Its new, its shiny and yada yada. So why would anyone get the older version of that which is  (Warband)?
Now I think the only two reasons you would touch it is:

More modding content available.
Many have said and still say to this day that modded warband makes singleplayer a whole lot replayable and enjoyable than the vanilla of both this game and Bannerlord. I say try to play vanilla singleplayer at least once for a little while and if you think something is missing, head on up to the workshop or nexus to spice things up a bit. I for some reason just played vanilla a couple times, aced it, and promised I would never touch it again. It can be lackluster a bit. 

If you really want the same thing but with better graphics then by all means go to Bannerlord and never touch this game.

Graphics aren't everything - but they're something. The sandbox-style RPG Mount & Blade: Warband is perhaps best compared to a work like the Bayeux Tapestry, a 230-foot long strip of cloth in northern France detailing one of the landmark events of the European Middle Ages. Background details barely show up at all, the people look two generations removed from Gumby, and the weavers couldn't even keep the lines on the border straight. Yet it's stunning to hold. Some parts look like kindergartners made it, but it has soul and heart, and its images remain better embedded in my memory than some of the busy masterworks of the renaissance.

Mount & Blade: Warband is the best game in the Mount & Blade series, as well as the best mix of a tactical battle game, a strategy game and a role playing game you'll find. It's also arguably one of the best games in the tactical battler and RPG categories alone. While many years old now, the game still holds up great.

The many positives include, but are not limited to:
[list]
[*]Solid combat mechanics that feel good, with directional attacks by mouse or keyboard, directional blocks, kicks, chamber blocks, shields working from the side and on the back, weapons with different strengths and solid mounted combat (including powerful lance attacks and horse archery.)

[*]Order system in battles so not only do you get into the feeling of being a warrior in combat, but also that of being a commander giving orders to their troops.

[*]Different battle terrains.

[*]Solid menus with overview of statistics, levels, gear, characters, fief ownership, fief prosperity, etc., including nested links to other relevant sites to currently viewed character, fief or faction.

[*]A nice, sizable world map for the time, with decent backstory and fillers for the fictional world of Calradia.

[*]A very moddable game for its time, having many, many mods made by talented and passionate developers over the years. You want to add magic, fantasy creatures and new factions to Calradia? You can do that. You want another fantasy world instead, built on the game mechanics of Warband? You can do that too. You rather want historical settings with time appropriate factions, lords and armors? Go for it. Even troop trees and skills can be edited, added and removed by modding.

[*]In addition to a solid singleplayer, multiplayer battles were a fun addition for friends and strangers to come together and battle it out.[/list]

The only negatives I can think of are:
[list]
[*]Somewhat annoying inventory system in the base game, with items generally snapping to the top even when you don't want it (still okay for its time though.)

[*]Even though Calradia is a fictional world, a few of the armors in the base game feel a bit anachronistic, with plate armor generally not fitting in with the rough time period and technology depicted in game. On the upside, mods and especially historical mods for the game generally do this better.[/list]

All in all Warband is a great game even without considering any nostalgic feelings, and with all of the solid mods out there on Nexusmods and/or Steam, you won't run out of entertainment with this one. Get it if you like RPGs, tactical medieval battles and/or you fancy any of the great mods for the game, such as for instance "1257AD - Enhanced Edition" (light bias may apply) or "Prophesy of Pendor."

Warband with Direct X9c is the better version than the Original M&B but still has many of the issues that effected the direct 7 version.

Mount and blade is a really fun game, if you play it right. You start on your horse and ride out in your early days in the fresh air and a new adventure! At that time youre not at war with anyone, so the world is peaceful.
Find the places where you can buy low and where you can sell higher. Bandits haunts the roads and the forest, sometimes they are too many but if you defeat them you can get nice gold. 
When you have enough money, you can buy an establishment to produce money every week adding more to your money.
It is about building up! Trade for good prices, make money from that, recruit mercenarys to fight for you, fighting and defeating enemies will make you strong and the more you recruit and the more you fight you will see them becoming more and stronger. 
Up in the north the searaiders can give you good chainmail armor and steel helmets, that will protect you well.

When you have a strong enough army you should join the land you want to fight for.
Heroicly ride to defeat your enemies, win victorys with your men, make them strong, with time you will be able to swear an oath to become the king's personal vassal, that gives the privelege of when you take over your first castle, you will keep it. 

Alot of gold can bring everything, great armors, great swords, tough and sturdy mercenaries and when you are mighty you will see it, on the battlefield it's pretty cool when you ride with your many and armored tough men, for your cause, with the command in your hands!

Mount and blade is an interesting game and the thing with it is that it is full of choices. You can choose to be a beast of strength, a tactical genius a tough trainer or a fast athlete. 
 Trading is also a big part of it, if you find the right places to trade to you can go from 0 to 50000 denars in about two days if you know how to do. 

It is realistic and you should maintain a good relationship with its masters, war chiefs and kings especially those you should ally with. It is very much about diplomacy. And certainly you feel like a lord when you sit high up in the saddle with shining armor and an army to protect you, a castle to go to.
I really got a good and happy exciting feeling from the game especially the first days I drove it. So much to do and see...
I have to say that I've seen that gleam in Mount and blade, the light of a wonderful time ...
Mount and Blace has it's charm. And when you in your clan siege and take over fiefs and castles, that is a good feeling. It has gotten me inspired about writing storys about of how we in the kingdom toast high for our victory and for health of our clan!

ABOUT IT

It's about making smart choices and if you succeed in defeating dangerous bandits you get gold, which you can save to make it more or buy a good horse or a nice shield.
The forests and the plain land are riddled with dangerous bandits, but once you have collected 50 men you can escape them.

With high charisma in stats, recruits follow and with leadership you command them. And you do really feel like a commander, it's a really good feeling.
The first people to gather and recruit are ordinary men and peasants, but after a little while of fighting you can upgrade. When you have enough strong and trained men or women(Sword sisters are awesome btw!) then it is time to join the kingdom you want to fight for.
If you successfully win over the enemy and capture the lords, then after some time you will be able to swear an oath to the king. You become his vassal. 
If you succeed in the tactics and cleverness of cutting a castle afterwards, with the high rank of vassal you can take over it.
What I think
After traveling the world for a long time and winning golden victories with your men, you feel like a true warlord and even better if you helped villages with a good heart(for that you also get honor) personally I've got nice golden memories from it.

BUT ALSO
When things go wrong and you lose money and things feel hopeless, then it's not fun, but when you together with the lords siege castles and citys and they say: ''I will not forget how we sieged Dhirim together!'' that feels very good and when your plans go well to.
But the game is much about that if you think and do wrong you will fall if you do the right choices you will rise!

CASTLE SIEGES
Are awesome and when you stand together with your friends(you can have the colors of your clan) that is cool. And you can nicely hide behind the walls of the cozy little castle, and it's highly immersive when the heroic music comes and you go to attack.

[h1]Flawed but Enjoyable[/h1]
I picked this game up during a Summer Sale after watching SovietWomble's video on it.

I can happily say that I love it.

Warband is essentially an updated version of the original Mount & Blade. I can't compare Warband to its predecessor or [i]With Fire and Sword[/i] since I haven't played them, nor can I comment on Napoleonic Wars since multiplayer isn't why I play.

The game takes place in the land of Calradia, a diverse land ripped apart by war with several kingdoms vying for control of the realm. You start the game by generating your backstory which affects what skill you start out with as well as your position among the Nobles of Calradia. You could be a commoner, a hunter, a bandit, or an impoverished noble.

Once you create and name your character, have fun. There is no linearity to the game. It is an open sandbox where you can do whatever it is you wish. Tell your own story, become a banner-man or a king or a queen. A champion of tournaments, or the leader of a mercenary band.

It is simply amazing, despite its outdated appearance and rough patches.

[b]Modding[/b]
This game was built for mods. TaleWorlds perfectly crafted this game catering to modifications. One notable mod I can name is [b]Diplomacy[/b] which adds more to the political aspects of the game as well as some other neat changes. I needn't say much about the full conversion mods on the workshop, it's always good to come back to a fresh campaign.

Now, the game sounds pretty cool right? Well, I wouldn't be calling it a flawed masterpiece if I didn't explain why.

[b]Flaws and Problems and Frustrations[/b]
I can only name three off the top of my head.

[b]AI[/b] - The AI in this game is unbelievably frustrating. The over world AI is fine, they do a good job, but the battle AI is the worst. Unless given proper commands they simply rush the enemy, bunch up together and get stuck on each other or consistently get in your way. It's like they have a one track mind.

the moment a battle starts, they are already rushing off ahead.

During melee's and Tournaments the AI can be especially unfair. Ganging up on the player, shield stunning. The Worst case of the AI's one track mindedness is especially noticeable during jousts where they will follow you in a circle trying to hit you, forcing you to maneuver yourself in a way that you can get them without being hit yourself.

[b]The Character can't keep still!![/b] - If this one doesn't frustrate people I'd be surprised. When making a character, you get only a window with your character standing there, close up on the face while you mess around with the sliders to give them your desired look.

Unfortunately, creating a character is a chore most of the time, thanks often times to the aforementioned problem. There is never a moment during the character creation process where the character won't move. this is especially annoying when trying to notice the subtle changes you make. I honestly wish TaleWorlds would release an update to freeze the characters in place while editing their appearance.

[b]Nothing more at the End[/b]
Once Calradia is conquered, either in your name or anothers', the game slows down. There's no more wars to fight, only bandits to slay and wealth to accumulate. I think the game should have had foreign invaders come in and storm the land, taking castle and what not forcing the ruling faction of Calradia to spring into action. Missed opportunity methinks.

[b]Personal Thoughts[/b]
While the AI issues and the character creation can be frustrating beyond belief, I do love this game.

It is addictive, and I would be lying if I said I didn't get stuck into this for hours at a time, upwards of five for two weeks before I can get a handle on that and start playing sparingly. I love being free to make my own story and take my characters where I want without them being restricted by level or story. [strike]I've never become king or queen in any play through since that is a lot of effort I never felt worth it to me.[/strike]


[b]Update:[/b] So around about early 2022, I actually did become a Queen in one of my newer characters and successfully conquered Calradia. It was honesty a miracle that I even managed to do it, and rule successfully at that.

It feels good to immerse myself in my role and roll with it for a while, problems be darned. The lack of dismemberment in the game has allowed me to imagine my attacks inflicting grievous wounds or beheading some poor soul even if it physically doesn't occur.

I have never touched the multiplayer and I do not intend to. I am extremely wary of online play in games, especially if the community turns out to be trash. And so, my experience with Warband shall remain singular.

I personally think it's a shame that the game lacks fantasy elements. I wouldn't mind it if Calradia had a history of magic and monsters and that information was sprinkled in he background.

the game being limited with what you can do and how much playable space you get in towns is also a shame. I am hoping Bannerlord makes the appropriate improvements where needed.

I truly love, Warband. it's one of my absolute favorites and well worth a go if you haven't played it already.

This game is awesome

This game is a wonderful game.

It is light on the computer and it is a game where you command your own army to fight on the battle field.

You recruit your armies and get to join any of the factions, or make your own.

This leads to tons of variety between playthroughs. From being a knight only small mercenary band, to leading the charging horse archers of the khan, this game has it all.

The real main plus is that it has a massive pool of mods to allow all sorts of types of warfare that you could want.

This game that was just a fantasy strategy game can suddenly be in the middle of the napoleonic era, or you could push it back to the rise of Islam.

You can even play mods with your other favorite fantasy worlds from other media.

The game also has a decent multiplayer scene still alive, its fun to hop on and do a large siege against enemy players, or to have one on one duels in an arena.

I don't recommend the napoleonic wars dlc though because it is basically dead now.

Mount and Blade Warband is such a nostalgic game when I think about it ! 

Since this day I trully appreciate the licence launched firstly in 2008 by the turkish editor Talesworlds. 

It the game wich made me spent the most of time when I compare it with the others that I own. I can't remember how many skarmish, loots, battles and sieges I have played ! 

At the current succes of Mount and Blade II Bannerlord wich is the succesor of Warband, lets have quick resume of the precedent opus, where this notoriety was born.  

From the beginning, you choose your character and your personnalize it in different ways (from the physics features to personnals skills).

You are gonna start your trip across Caraldia with barely enough coins to feed yourself. 

You'll have fews options to counter this. 

- Loot.
- Scam.
- Fight the bandits.
- Engage yourself for a lord service with a band of warriors.

Otherwise you can straight engage fews guys in your squad to keep a chance to survive. Although your mens'll protect to keep you alive, you have to pay them. Each wages'll definited in cases of the class and positions of your troups. You can meet and hire some companion in tavern as well. 

Every companion is working as the same as your proper character in this features as (level, stats, skills). But be carefull, your companion might quit your squad at any moment if you have bad behavior for looting, scaming, crimes... 

During the battle you might get a fight into a castle as attacker or defender. It'll be your task to be the most strategist and organized ! 

An ennemy wave in numerical superiority agains you and it's over ! 

During the standard fights, you have to supervise every parts of the battlefield. Indeed, If you and your army is located on the top of hill or in the other side of a river you may have chance to counter the ennemy or shoot them with your crossbows and bows. 

The strong point of this game is the immersion and that what I like. 

When your reputation is building up step to step, the differents kingdom will know more about you. You'll have the choice to build up strong alliance, trade with them, marry with one of lady (daughters of the lords) or perhaps be in war with them. 

Every actions has to be smartly evaluate if you don't want to be surrunded by the ennemies or send into a deep cold and dark  dungeon. 

Finally the BEST part of this games are the diverses modes playable. 

Thanks to the generous community which procures extra hours to us for enjoy it ! There are for diferents tastes ! Antic, viking, middle-age, even for the fans movies or series we can find Game of Thrones or Star Wars adaptation ! It's huge ! 

So now, put your helmmet, wears-up your irons gloves, look after your war horse, feed your mens and take away your best sword, because the conquest of Calradia is waiting for you.

Warband (native) is overall a decent game that is fun at first, but quickly becomes a frustrating wrangle with the computer-controlled factions and lords.

The base game gets somewhat tiring quickly (~35-40 hrs). Your first experiences with everything will be incredibly fun and exciting. Large battles, castle and city sieges, getting your fiefs, all of those are great fun your first pass. Despite this, the general gameplay loop begins to become a bit tedious. Once you're in a position of power within a kingdom, you do a lot of sitting around and waiting. There's always something to do, of course, but doing nothing and waiting for the AI to call you to action or to give you something new is often the best option. 

The more hours you put into the game, you will quickly realize that you are the both the most overpowered thing on the entire map and also completely unable to do anything of meaning without "help" (meat shielding) from the AI. It is entirely too frustrating to be appointed marshal only to have your computer-controlled army run away from you to go defend a Very Poor village when you're trying to take a city. 

I assume there are many mods that fix the myriad issues that the aging base game has, but at what point are you playing a different game in the same engine?

Overall, would recommend it if you are looking for something old-school that you'll get about ~30 hours of gameplay out of.

There are no other games, RTS or otherwise, that give you the balance of sense of control, and actual involvement in combat itself, besides this one. It is a perfect mix of strategy and skill, as having only one of those options alone will never award you victory in this game. You know that the game is balanced upon this, as the battles that you are not personally involved in (order troops to attack without you), you always lose more men than you should have. 
          The AI of enemies is superb, especially for a game of this age. The scale of battles is greater than any other game of the era, especially considering just how many ai's can be on-screen at once, each in their own battle. Builds are interesting little tweaks to how the game can be played, with just enough spin to keep it interesting, but not allowing for the game to be completely cheesed by a particular build. There's even town management, investments, diplomacy, tournaments, training fields, random encounters, and at least 80 different "armors", as well as romance, reading, and so on. it still holds up, gameplay-wise, to this day, and that is why the core gameplay itself was not changed much in the sequel game, Bannerlords II.
       The bulk of complaints to be made about this game largely revolve around limitations of it's time, like textures and models, but they are still great looking even now. There's also a bunch of outside-of-combat skills and small details not present in the original game, compared to the sequel. To clearly see this list, look up "Differences between M&BWB and M&BBL2". All in all, if you enjoy RTS games, fantasy games, medieval combat games, action games, adventure games, or even simulators, you should consider playing, as this game may be 100 or even 1000 hours of play material to you.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

mount & blade: warband is a 2010 standalone expansion to the original mount and blade from 2008. developed by taleworlds entertainment, warband expands on the original by adding a 6th faction to the base game, increasing the amount of political features in the game, adds the ability to start your own faction eventually (the best addition), among many other improvements. there's obviously the strategy element but there's also a action-rpg element as you go from the strategy of navigating the world map while also having too go into first/third person for big battles between you and your army and the enemy army. it can be very fun and chaotic, which is why this game is so good. it blends the two genres beautifully and everything in each aspect of the game is awesome and detailed and just almost creates a sandbox where you can go and do anything you want and take as long as you want, and that's not even including the fact that you can mod the game and add in so many extra things, all right through the steam workshop. there's a steep learning curve, but once you finally get it, it clicks and the game takes on a whole new identity and you feel so much freedom in the ability to basically go wherever and do whatever you want with whoever. this is one of the greatest games on steam and one i can't recommend enough to basically anyone, especially strategy game enthusiasts. getting this for 75% off is an absolute steal and i'm so glad i saw this on sale in 2021 and decided to pull the trigger finally.
