I bough this game many years ago and even though it offered me many hours of entertainment there's one thing that absolutely killing it for me, and that is lack of polish. To be more exact combat and character interaction with environment is fundamentally broken. 

(Note: This review references Multiplayer almost entirely, most of these issues are nonexistent or minimal in Single player)

1. COMBAT CONTROL

It's clunky, imprecise and fundamentally broken. How so you may ask? Well, the attack/ block direction is controlled by movement of your mouse. (there is an option to change it to your movement keys WASD, but then if you want to move to the left and block right swing you're in trouble) The feature would be alright if it actually worked properly, but 50% of the time it does not and as far as I know there is no ability to key bind attack/block direction. (here I'm talking about multiplayer) 

To give you an example. You can play round one of some map and do great, get many kills, score hits, do damage. Then on round two everything changes, all of a sudden you can't hit anyone. Your 1st thought must be hey it must be my ping, so you check it and see that it's exactly the same as last round. Then you think to your self, hey maybe this round the players are better than I am, but you look at their names see that guy that you dominated twice last round now all of a sudden is untouchable and kills you in one or two hits. Now you start wonder what is going on? Am I going insane? Is he hacking? You ask in chat what is happening, everyone tells you to "GIT GUD" and calls you a noob. In reality it's none of the above. It is just the game it self, a broken combat system that has more in common with a game of roulette than a sword fight. 

For some reason there is also an inconsistent induced lag for any action. Say you want to do a right swing, you find a target, aim up, get your swing ready and release it, but your swing goes through the target, you get stabbed and die. You once again wonder what is happening and find out that for some reason now when you release LMB for an attack there is a ~.5 sec delay even though 2 min ago it was ~.1 sec, so you adjust. You go for an attack and again your attack misses, you get stabbed and die. You check your delay now it's ~.2 sec, so you start looking at your ping and find out that it varies by only 10ms at worst through out the entire round. So what's the problem? 

Often times you will find yourself looking all the way in the air or at the ground, due to the attacker's continuous stab or overhead attacks. There isn't much you can do about it, because if you try to change you view your attack/ block direction will go with it.

There is something fundamentally wrong with hit detection, hit boxes and combat speed; and may God have mercy on your soul if you're fighting in tight quarters or surrounded by friendlies. Your weapon will get stuck on everything and will be borderline impossible to strike the enemy without accidentally striking a friendly. From what I know this issue is only present in Warband and its derivatives, not the original Mount & Blade.

An additional frustrating issue that is exclusive to Napoleonic Wars is the weapon mode switch (X). Sometimes you press it and it works, your musket is now in a "bayonet mode", but other times you press it and it doesn't switch, so you press it again it doesn't work. By that time it is too late and you get stabbed by the enemy, because a basic and crucial game function didn't work. 

2. INTERACTION WITH THE ENVIRONMENT 

This issue is not as evident in Warband (Native) as is in Napoleonic Wars, but what it boils down to is interaction with cannons, barricades, horses etc. In order for one to interact with any object you must be in an exact precise position and look direction in order for it to work. The worst of all is that this issue doesn't exist with the doors, they work flawlessly and respond immediately to interactions. You come to "arms reach" of a door, look at any part of it, press F and it works, 100% of the time. This might make one wonder, if interaction with doors works so well, then what the hell is wrong with everything else. Why, when even I want to get up on a horse I have to walk up to an exact position and look at a specific point and even then it requires multiple tries and "F" presses for it to work.

Why when I place down barricades as an Engineer, in order for my build hammer to interact with the barricade and build it I have to move around and swing like an idiot 5x more than necessary, because 2/3 of the build hammer swings aren't recognized. 
Like before all of these issues are not consistent, sometimes the game just works and you have a blast. 5 minutes later, everything goes to shit and you're left wondering what happened. It's a roller coaster of functionality and I simply don't understand why. How do you build a program that sometimes works and sometimes doesn't unless you do it on purpose, due to incompetence or sheer malice.

This game earned TaleWorlds so much money that they could've hired someone to at least patch up some of these problems 50x over, but they didn't. Why? I don't know.
 
From what I've seen of the new Bannerlord footage, it suffers from exact same problems, but of course rabbit fans will defend it to their dying bed. Saying it's just beta, give it time. Warband has been receiving updates up until recently and Bannerlord has been in development for roughly 8 years. We're ways past the "it' just Beta" excuse.


3. LINUX PORT

This is just an issue for Linux users, I played on both Windows and Linux. Linux version is just poorly made, even more so than the original. The module selection doesn't work and you have to fix it or change modules manually in game files. Graphical issues and performance issues. It's mediocre at best. 


4. COMMUNITY

This game has borderline cult like following. They can take no criticism what so ever, the game is perfect and it is just you who suck and should "play more" to get better. I expect nasty comments on this review, so feel free to call me a noob all you want, but that won't fix the issues mentioned. 


CONCLUSION

I will continue playing the game because there are still many good things about it, mainly in Single player, but I feel hesitant when it comes to recommending it to someone else.

If you think I misstated something or I'm plain out wrong feel free to correct me or add to my list.

I think my favorite reason as to why this game is so nice is because, for me, it has the perfect level of abstraction in a role-playing strategy game. Games like Battle Brothers or Darkest Dungeon are really zoomed in with very little strategic abstraction (you directly control all party member's moves), and games like CK2 are really zoomed out (tens of thousands fight and die and all you see are numbers). Warband is zoomed in just enough so you can feel the power of commanding a big army (or a small band of hooligans) while still providing the feeling that you as a character meaningfully impact the outcomes of battles, right down to your sword strokes. Couple that with a modding community that has produced some of the best player-crafted experiences I've ever played, and you got a recipe for a real banger of a title. There are some multiplayer-only mods that don't have as many players as in their heyday, but the single-player mods still shine to this day (with the added benefit of Bannerlord being out already, meaning all the mods out now for Warband are more or less finished and aren't going to need updates anymore). On top of that, Taleworlds as a developer is really close to their community in a way that's pretty cool.

Now a personal note: I bought this game because I checked out a book called Ivanhoe in middle school and fell in love with medieval stuff. Then, one glorious middle school summer, I put in like 600 hours over 4 months. The cycle was literally: wake up at 9am, eat breakfast, hang out until noon, microwave the chicken tendies, then play mount and blade for 6-8 hours. Years later, when mental illness reared its ugly head, this game was one of a few anchors that kept me going. This game literally changed my life for the better, and I will very likely play Warband into my old age. I love it with my whole heart, and I encourage anyone who likes RPGs, strategy games, and games with really tight combat systems.

One of the best medieval simulators and roleplaying games on steam, Mount and Blade Warband is a unique game that few other games emulate, where you play as a single character in third or first person, but can gather an army that follows and fights with you and obeys your commands on the battlefield, and that you can use to conquer and pillage towns and castles on the over world map. The combat is great, fighting on foot you can block and attack in four different directions which keeps you on your toes while also having more advanced moves like parries and weapon chambering. Horse back gameplay is also great, some of the best in most games that have mounted combat, as long as you aren't going up or down a hill as it slows you significantly. Your character also has stats that get better over time making you more and more effective at combat as the game goes on, especially when you get better gear and feel like a true knight butchering peasants.
Gameplay outside the battlefield is also good, as Calradia, the low fantasy world in which the game takes place, feels immersive and alive, you can interact with the various lords, go to each town castle and village and walk around them, and interact with them such as doing trade, raiding them, or eventually conquering and ruling them. You can join the various kingdoms as a mercenary or pledge yourself to them and become a proper lord, and the game offers various roleplaying opportunities. If you want to play the entire game as a peasant, you can, if you want to be a bandit, you can, if you want to be a merchant you can. You can participate in tournaments, attend feasts, marry a noble, and conquer the continent. You can even form your own kingdom if you don't want to serve one of the starting kingdoms. 
The gameplay is great, although graphically Mount and Blade has never been a good looking game even back when it came out, and the sound design is serviceable, however if you're playing this game it's more for the game play than the graphics. Music is also serviceable, nothing really notable. 
This game really shines however with the modding community. This game has many great mods available for it and chances are you'll be spending more time in one of the many conversion mods to play in your favorites settings than you will in the base game, especially since these mods add many new features that greatly improve the immersive gameplay.
If you enjoy being a medieval warrior that gets to conquer things, and don't care about graphics, this game is a definite buy.

These 400 hours have flown by. Started as a nothing in Calradia and rose to the sole ruler of this land. It took a few starts until I got a feel for game mechanics, but the learning curve is gentle and honestly I didn't NEED to restart, failure is pretty forgiving. It's easy to get wrapped up in the adventure you're crafting for yourself.

Admittedly, probably only about 1/3 of those 400 hours are on the native version. The rest are in mods and as much as I love native there's many more adventures to be had. You can fight in feudal Japan, Dark Ages Britain, Middle Earth, fantasy worlds, Ancient Greece, Calradia in the renaissance/1900s/etc, North America in the Civil War, etc etc etc...and etc etc etc. There are tons of mods of diverse lands (but also quality).

Okay, I'm going to try for criticisms. Even with mods, sometimes it can feel repetitive. Some of the politics can be light. Juggling the interests of my Lords doesn't interest me, once I got a few castles established under my rule I lost some interest in playing (once things got easier and repetitive and I start a new campaign).

I can't compare to the sequel, I haven't gotten it (yet). But I've definitely gotten my money's worth out of this game and have enjoyed it immensly.

My life has been in a downward spiral ever since I reinstalled this game. I wake up, I play Warband, my day is ruined. Rinse, repeat, ad infinitum. I'm a shell of myself. A husk. Every moment I'm not playing Warband, I'm thinking about playing Warband. It's consumed me. I want every achievement. I want to play every mod. I don't care for sleep, nor food, nor water. All I care about is getting 10,000 denars for another dyeworks. All I care about is recruiting enough men to stock my garrisons, hoping to dissuade my enemies from attacking me. My social life is in shambles. I'm now unemployed. I'm no longer in college. My girlfriend hates me. I've given all I have for this game, and because of that, I now feel attached to it. If I were to tear myself away now, everything would've been in vain. I don't know how much longer I can keep this cruel facade in tact, but I have no choice but to press forward into the cold depths of the unknown abyss. Anyways, yeah, it's a pretty good game. I'd definitely recommend it.

Mount and Blade: Warband is a broken mess trying its best to be an RPG, a grand strategy, a real-time strategy, a tycoon simulator, and a political investigation at the same time. It does none of these things very well, but it does them all acceptably.

It is, possibly, the most ambitious video game ever made.

Obviously, I love it, despite its mountain of setbacks, bugs, and issues.

There are a multitude of Total Conversion mods that provide you entirely new worlds and mechanics.

Definitely worth exploring if you're into anything from Warhammer to AoE.

Want to start off as a noble house? Nope. Even if your father was a lord or noble and you are a lesser noble, no one acknowledges your banner.

Want to hire an army to fight in the war? Nope. Hiring units is ridiculously expensive and every unit besides peasants are out of your budget.

Want to do tasks for a lord to gain his trust? Nope. Most of the "tasks" involve raiding bases or killing armies of bandits. Completely impossible when you have only a few peasants by your side and can't afford to recruit more.

Want to roam the countryside and find a better place to start? Nope. Prepare to get stopped every 10 feet by a pack of raiders or bandits, demanding either your money or your life.

Trying to at least finish the main quest? Good luck. On top of raiders and bandits ensuring you can't move without being robbed, and being unable to hire any defense, you also have to deal with the Lannisters attacking you on sight. Usually outnumbering you 10 to 1.

Out of options, you decide to enlist in a lord's army to at least make some money. Well here's the thing:

You only make 50-100 stags a week (not enough to hire men of your own, let alone keep them fed and armed). You don't get to keep the armor that you're given by enlisting. Resigning reduces your reputation with the lord so you can no longer do anything for them. And worst of all, enlisting in an army consists of sitting there AFK 90% of the time trying to scrape together enough money to survive.

Every so often I return to this game, which I have played for 1,000 hours, in frustration. This is a game that exists on the fringe in many ways. It's not a particularly common genre: the most similar game in the last few years would be the last Pirates! remake. It's enjoyed by a number of people, but never reached the huge success of even the most popular indie PC games. It offers many mechanics that are challenging both to one's skill and to repetitive industry tropes.

In a decade marked by re-releases of Skyrim, medieval combat simulators that run almost entirely on scripted sequences like Kingdom Come, "meta"-based fighting games like For Honor, and Chivalry killers like Mordhau, Warband offers remarkably unadorned, yet skillful combat. There's no magic or executions. There's no shoving or unlockable abilities. There are no unblockable attacks, yet these are the very reasons that you feel your victories are earned. Mount & Blade differs from these games in that it's uniquely plausible and skill-based. To succeed in the game you don't just have to have a high-leveled character or to read a forum post about an exploit - you have to actually understand the game. Regrettably, if you stare into this abyss for too long, the demons start coming out, and you begin to understand why I refuse to recommend it after all this time.

You see, Warband is great, but it has a number of problems. Bugs, technical and mechanical, poison your experience a bit. If you don't find the secret option to force single threading you may find the game crashes frequently or NPC AI may behave strangely, such as when prisoners you're rescuing suddenly turn on you. Even if you do find the option, you will occasionally see lords of vanquished factions floating around freely, like ghosts, unable to join anyone, or NPCs floating after the siege tower they've been standing on departs, or opponents in the arena melee inexplicably teaming up against you and then freezing like robots once you're knocked out. In multiplayer, the emphasis is on dealing maximum damage as quickly as possible, as the actual tactical component is missing, and as such Warband is infamous for its "naked men with 2-handers." Ultimately these little niggling problems pile up on your conscience. An optimist says, "don't worry, it'll be fixed in the sequel." A pessimist says:

"The sequel has been in development for over 9 years, has no release date, will probably be sold for $60, omits the most requested feature of campaign multiplayer, and buying Warband now only serves to lengthen its development time. On top of it all, there's no guarantee there won't be a host of new bugs to annoy us for an entire decade."

This is the heart of the matter. Why should I pay $60 for arena AI that behaves like it should, or for oft-bragged about graphical features that predate the first alpha of the first game? What I want is a functional game, campaign co-op, a reason not to run directly toward my enemy and hit them with a 2H sword in multiplayer. When I talk about the game with my brother or friends, people who play games as a social event and not as a private addiction consuming their free time, I want to mention they can play it along with me - not just nominally, but actually experiencing the part of the game that made it popular. TaleWorlds have literally spent all but 3 months of this decade building a sequel with virtually undemanded features like accurately animated horse reins while their characters still have potato faces, or children that allegedly take over the game when you die even though a war that goes on for as long as a human's maturation time is absurd, and so on. They are now just skating along on old revenues from their periodic latecomer sales of this video game - a video game that they don't intend to truly fix unless you pay them full retail price for the next game.

For these reasons I cannot recommend this very interesting and addictive game.

Edit: 3 years later, the sequel finally has a release date, but the game itself is a train wreck of broken promises and, like Warband, will be abandoned with countless bugs and missing features after release. This is not a developer you want to support.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

This is my second introduction to M&B:W, and my first and only game in the series that I've played so far.

My first attempt was to play this on xbox, which the controls were just terrible but it gave me an idea of what I was getting into. Here on PC none of these issues persisted, combat is so much easier, despite still a steep learning curb, and having that little bit of knowledge of what to expect in how the game worked for me before has paid off.

The game overall is enjoyable even though there is a rather steep learning curb for it. The graphics and the AI are a bit dated but considering the age of the game, this is to be expected. But AI is where this game has its shortfalls. Every ally gets in your way during any conflict, no matter what you're doing. I end up relegating myself to doing wide sweeps around my own army and attacking enemies from the rear because I simply cannot get close to enemy units otherwise to do anything else. Meanwhile, the enemy AI goes into a state of ultimate hyper-aggression once you pick a nation to join and hunt you down in a massive wave of the combined forces of their entire nation, and will, in fact, hunt you to the ends of the earth for it.

I am a little over 60 days into the game, I have less than 40 units in my main army, mostly a wide mix of cavalry with a growing horde of well-trained commoners. For an example of the latter of ultimate hyper-aggression, I tested this multiple times. I join a conflict, I reach a siege point, and the entire enemy force bares arms to over 1000 and wipes me and the attackers off the map. I don't join up and the enemy horde is a no-show, but still exists idly somewhere, and the army I would have joined takes the city without further resistance. If I don't join I don't become a mercenary, which is the point of the game, if I do join the enemy horde instantly targets my position in overwhelming force, because instead of joining the Siege I left the area, only to find the 'horde' ignoring the siege entirely to come after me, crossing literally 2 nations to do it by the time they caught up with me.

Doesn't make a lot of sense, and maybe it's just me, but I am just having fun hunting down criminals and amassing a militia of peasants regardless.

One of the most interesting concepts for a truly open world RPG, Mount and Blade: Warband is basically a simulation of being a medieval god of war. After the introduction, the core gameplay loop is essentially traveling from location to location gathering soldiers, raising enough money via quests and pillaging to feed your growing army, and eventually waging war on whoever angered you that particular day. 

The game's controls are a little difficult to get the hang of, and certain weapons feel way more useful than others (archery is especially effective at taking down enemies quickly without putting yourself in harm’s way). The AI also isn't exactly amazing since all they basically do is charge headfirst into one another until someone falls down dead. But as the size of your battles increase, you start to really feel like a hero on the battlefield, commanding your troops as you charge into enemy lines and wreak havoc. 

The graphics aren't the greatest, as many people feel the need to point out, but that really doesn't impact the fact that the game itself is endlessly replayable with hours upon hours of content to consume. If you're looking for a great RPG in a realistic medieval setting with large-scale battles, then it doesn't get much better than this.

A fantastic game in every regard, even without mods. It's like if a medieval RISK board game let you participate in the battles. 

Your actual participation is fun because the combat is surprisingly great with being able to respond to attacks at different angles. You have to respond to blocks, incoming projectiles, and charging horses. You also can give orders based on the current environment and the makeup of your army, such as ordering your crossbowmen to take the high ground on a hill while the cavalry charge. I never got tired of besieging castles, clearing out bandits, participating in tournaments, and going head to head with rival nobles. You can customize yourself and companions by getting armor, horses, and weapons. All towns offer different goods and different prices, making exploration more rewarding.

Outside of combat you move around on an elaborate chessboard where the simulator chunk of the game comes from.
There's different factions with unique troops you'll be training or fighting, and your actions matter relative to your reputation with other nobles. Climbing up that ladder with the other vassals to become likable so that you can be rewarded more territories. There's factors like honor, renown, and right to rule that determine your standing with the rest of Calradia. You can get married, take tasks from other vassals in your faction, rebel, recruit, attack, and everyone seems to respond to it. There's also your troops morale that requires you to manage the size of it, your food supply, and other tasks that I really didn't find tedious because of how interlaced it was with the exciting parts of the game.

Mount & blade Warband is one of few games in its genre, and despite being over 12 years old nothing else has surpassed it. while its still clunky even for an older game, even the sequel has not bested the feel of Warband.
The combat gives you a unique first person perspective on warfare in the medieval period.command your troops to outsmart, outmaneuver, and massacre your enemies. engage in political intrigue, either to install a pretender to a kingdoms throne or seize your own territory and declare your own empire, your fate is in your hands. 
or forgo the glory, honor, and bloodshed and become a traveling merchant or a vagrant champion fighting in city's tournament. 

basically: game good buy game.

The Soundtrack of the Napoleonic Wars DLC is really great.

Nowadays you won't find a game with such a simple but at the same time competitive combat system.

Great tools for clans, custom servers and community events (and also modifications if you like that).

One of the healthiest competitive scenes i have ever witnessed, still going in 2022. Tournaments are well organised and fun.

Most of the players are guys between 15 and 30 who are interested in history, and that's great between it leads to a common ground.

Sadly the successor Bannerlord is not a viable alternative to Warband.

A great classic game for all medieval fans.

I started playing this game in 2017 and have done a few re-runs ever since.

Mount & Blade: Warband is dated, with graphics that already looked old back when it was originally released. But honestly, this game has so much heart and is such a unique experience that I wouldn't let that hold you back. It is hard not to lose yourself in this world, which is surprisingly rich and imaginative. There is story for those that seek it but also suffeciently addictive gameplay loops that can keep you entertained if you were to ignore it all.

If you like RPGs, fantasy and strategy, then this game might scratch several of those itches. If the vanilla game doesn't compel you then make use of the vast wealth of mods to finetune your experience. I really don't think there is anything like Mount & Blade and am looking forward to Warband after its full release.

A sandbox classic that, although making me shudder when I first saw its graphics, soon got me hooked since it's just so addicting and refreshing to build up your character from absolute nothing to be a raid-party leader, commander, marshal and eventually even a king (provided you want to go down that route). Absolutely nothing is handed to you as you first have to make a name for yourself to even be respected by the nobility and raise your troops yourself from peasant villages whilst trying to keep those poor buggers alive by providing them with food and battle experience without losing them all in an uneven fight until they are proficient enough to survive battle on their own. Or you can roam the world as a bandit and set upon every peasant and nobleman that crosses your path. Or maybe you want to become the medieval Jeff Beezos and just be a filthy rich trader that tries to outwit the shifting economy of the kingdoms of Calradia, profiteering off of war and atrocities like no other by price gouging raided cities in dire need of food after they've been sieged for weeks. It's all yours for the taking

Furthermore this sandbox is highly moddable because of its simplicity and that's exactly what the community did: Lord of the rings, Game of thrones, the time of the roman imperium, the 30 years war or the Sengoku Jidai, it's all there.

ive only had it around an hour and already consider it one of the best 20 dollars ive ever spent. Why?
its an Action-RPG with good, solidly deep and satisfying melee combat, archery, and cavalry riding and generally feels a bit like Daggerfall in its open-endedness and sandbox nature. There is virtually no story to follow here, only you get to choose how a single character's narrative works within Calradia. Its all too commonplace for an RPG to feature the player character in a fashion that is too grandiose--Skyrim's protagonist is always the Dovahkiin, the protagonist of Fallout New Vegas is always the catalyst for the battle of the Hoover Dam, regardless of what side they decide to fight for. In M&B, you are just you. are you a nobleman who's taken up the sword to participate in tournaments all around the realm? are you a lowborn bandit, plundering trade routes for money, killing civilians all over the place? are you a common sellsword, taking up arms for whomever pays best? are you a merchant? are you the count of a village or the king of an entire land, in this game, it REALLY is up to you, character creation is surprisingly robust and due to the nature of the game world's design, choices really kinda do matter (not for story purposes, but for lore, trade, and personal canon purposes). Mechanically, aside from the obvious classic Elder Scrolls comparisons, it plays like a large-scale battle game, with you able to command units at a pretty granular level. Others make comparisons to Total War, and while my experience with that series is limited, i'd agree. The real kicker is the depth of interaction with the world. Instead of quests that direct you to remote caves and hideaways, most quests are battles for resources and clout, taking place near villages and castles and under command of one of the key leading figures around the realm. Or you could be leading the forces for yourself, looking to take your own kingdom. Think Crusader Kings mixed with Daggerfall and you've got a pretty decent place to start thinking about mount and blade. its not a hard game to actually place, but like both Daggerfall and CK, the beginner's learning curve is pretty severe--if you are a gamer who likes making their own head canon, such as getting overly attached to specific XCOM soldiers, this is a great choice and its price is very hard to argue with, just be prepared for a significantly dated looking game and a bit of a curve; what you'll end up with is one of the best "choose your own adventure" games out there, only really easily compared to Divinity or again, Daggerfall.

Late review as Bannerlord is already out and I have owned this for years beforehand, but Warband is a great game with great mods. It is probably my favorite game of all time but that will be surpassed if Bannerlord gets fully finished and gets as many mods as Warband does. Most of my time is probably in Native Warband (or Diplomacy mod as that is just QoL changes and doesn't do anything drastic to Native) and Viking Conquest DLC. However, the mods for this game are insane and a lot of people spend more time there than in the base game.
     The base game could be described as a "historically authentic RPG." It's not historically accurate as Calradia is not real and neither are its kingdoms, but there is no magic, all the kingdoms are inspired by IRL cultures (Khergit = Mongols, Nords = Scandinavia etc.), and the combat and gear are authentic (reasonably within the time this game was made)  to different medieval peoples while still giving each faction their own unique identity and fighting style as this is still a game so it makes sense to have some factions excel where others fall behind. 
     Viking Conquest leans more into historical accuracy as it focuses on real cultures, religions and kingdoms in the late 800s after the Great Heathen Army invaded Northern Britain and formed the Danelaw. You have Angles, Saxons, Norse, Gaels, Frisians, and Britons. The factions fight more similar and are armed more similar than in Native as the scope of the DLC is the British Isles, Southern Scandinavia and Frisia. The heavy differences lie in culture, religion, etc. This one is really immersive and makes up for its lack of variety with how much it makes me feel involved in the storm of war and politics following the establishment of the Danelaw.
     I have spent most of my time in what comes with the game, but in terms of mods, there are many spotlights: Prophecy of Pendor,  Perisno, Game of Thrones mods, Lord of the Rings mods, a Warhammer mod, a Star Wars mod, Sengoku Jidai Japan mod (Gekokujo), Napoleonic Wars singleplayer (L'Aigle), 1500s Southeast Asia (Suvarnabhumi Mahayuth), 1930s-40s (The Red Wars), and many more. I have not played a lot but I enjoy The Last Days of the Third Age as I am a big Tolkien fan and have enjoyed many hours of Elvish archery, Orc hordes, and Dwarvish steel. Needless to say, it is my favorite mod and I recommend it after you get used to basic M&B mechanics from Native.
     So, I recommend Mount & Blade: Warband. Even if you have Bannerlord or if Bannerlord has this amount of mods in the future, you should still go back and try Warband, janky and bare-bones graphics as it may be.

The core mechanics of the game are pretty fun, but there is SO MUCH JANK in this game. Crashes, corrupt saves, bizarre unit behaviour at times, siege AI is totally bizarre/illogical and such a grind.

With mods and/or cheats, the game is playable, but the JANK IS REAL, and you will most likely encounter some seriously frustrating moments.

I can't recommend this one to the average gamer.

This game is addictive. The character-creation process gives each character some individuality, if you have a character concept and follow it (rather than optimizing stats), and the appearance options are flexible. The sandbox character of the game (and the size of the world) give great flexibility for one's goals, whether to join an exiting faction as a vassal, to build one's own empire, or simply to be a caravan trader. One can make moral choices that affect one's reputation. Also, if one gets tired of the vanilla game, there are dozens of mods that can change the game setting immensely. I really enjoy the Viking Conquest mod offered by the studio, which is an official studio-made version of Brytenwalda (the studio hired the Brytenwalda creators to make the VC mod). Finally, I like the variety of equipment and the fact that different grades of it are available.

PS I just finished the story mode in Viking Conquest and feel so sad that it's over! It added so much depth to the game!

Now clocked up 10 hours of game play on this, clocked up 113 on the original, this expansion is actually more like a sequel better game play all round. the diversity of missions and the extra political missions and intrigue add  a lot to the immersive depth of the game. The market is more complex and provides challenge to know the best prices to buy and sell at. One area where i would have a little moan would be the directional swinging of the weapons, no matter which system i use now i cannot get the same precision and ease of fighting that i got in the first game. It is a minor grumble as i cut my way through dozens of enemy's without issue. I can't believe this game and the original were made so long ago, the graphics and game play do give it the air of a modern game, but as they say, the classics are the best. Loving it and very much enjoying starting out again, hoping this time round to get to become king. Buy at any price, well worth it.

This game man. Let me run you through my first good play through.
1. Start as an impoverished noble son, setting out to make a name for myself.
2. Collect a few Vaegir men and start hunting down bandit parties patrolling outside of Reyvadin.
3. Find their lair and destroy it.
4. Compete in a local tournament and win, gaining more renown.
5. Over time, my party becomes a band of warriors, and a herald comes to say that the Khan of the Khergits wants me as a vassal. I respectfully decline, as my warriors do not want to live in the snow.
6. Eventually, King Yaro of the Vaegirs sends a herald to offer me vassalage. I accept and am given a small fief that I care for.
7. Start making money with my fief and workshops.
8. We war against the Nords, I take multiple castles for the king and have many victories.
9. Nords are done for.
10. Turn towards the Swaedians, and my party of 100 men rip through Harlaus and his knights. 
11. Swaedians done for.
12. Yaro calls me his personal champion and after a high ranking lord defects, Yaro gives me THREE TOWNS.
13. MAKE BANK FOR MONTHS.
14. Vaegiers start destroying the Rhodoks. Seeing that we will quickly own half the map, I know that if I ever want to be King of Calradia, I cannot allow my own faction (who I love) to keep growing.
15. I defect, and Yaro is sad to see me go.
16. I attack the Rhodoks from the other side and take Almera Castle, declaring it property of the United Kingdom of Calradia.
17. Sweep across the Rhodoks and take Jelkala as our capital. By now I have 8 vassals who all like me and own fiefs.
18. Old Rhodok territory is now mine.
19. Sarranids war against me in the summer. I announce a crusade, and with all 12 of my vassals at my side, we conquer them completely by autumn. The sultan offered peace many times, but we denied.
20. It was now only myself, the Khergits, and the Vaegirs. 
21. As soon as the Khergits war the Vaegiers, we strike and take all the Swaedian land once held by the Vagi.
22. I want Sargoth. Yaro sits upon its throne.
23. We march on Sargoth. Yaro meets me outside, and I shed a tear as I charge towards his army. We win.
24. Now the Khergits are the only ones left in the snowy mountains, and over a long two years we take their lands.
25. Calradia is united. I am king. I walk out of my palace doors in Sargoth, and see my empire. Arch Silverblood has made a name for himself.

Love it mechanically, one of the best horse riding, horse battle and archery controls I ever experienced. Puts you in a perspective of what kind of power the cavalry holds and what kind of brutal chaos is the medieval battlefield. On top of mechanics there are classic role-playing elements and surprisingly unique concept with what I can describe as mercenary sandbox strategy. Also m&b has well balanced and expansive trading system which potentially allows you to earn money without ever engaging in battles, which feels like playing a completely different game.

M&B is rough around the edges and occasional bugs, glitches and strange npc dialogue influence the overall experience substantially, the longer game goes along, the more notable the unpolished nature of the game and, possibly, budgetary constraints are.

Sill amazing experience for me. Has things other, more marketable games couldn't do better

On its own, it is a great game and there are not many like it. 
But I'm not alone when I say it is the mods that truly elevate it to best game. 
Here are some of my recommendations.
Historical mods: Aut Caesar aut nihil (Rome), 1257 AD - Enhanced edition (Crusades), Gekokujo DER (Japan warring times), Between Empires (WWI), American Civil war revived, Age of Arthur, Bryten walda (dark ages), Sparta (ancient greece).
Fantasy mods: Prophesy of pendor, Perisno, Paradigm worlds (this one is a mix of scifi), ACOK + Ice and fire (both Game of thrones mods).
Vanilla based-mods (stays closer to the factions): Bannerpage, Diplomacy, Floris, Novas Aetas.

There is much more mods to be found on Moddb, Nexus mods, steam workshop, or Talesworlds forums. These are just the mods I really liked in my time playing.

If you haven't played this game, it is most likely because you are worried about the way it looks, how it might play, or if this is even a stable franchise amidst an over-saturated fantasy oriented world. These are silly things to worry about. 

Mount & Blade: Warband is an experience unlike any other. Ultimate control over politics, religion, territory and money. Imagine Total War but you play your commander, and he starts from nothing. Scraping your way to the top is so satisfying, especially because you make every decision from the get-go.

There is no sandbox game like Warband. Try as they might, none of them are the same thing.

Lances are great. 50 to 1 and you can win, as long as you have a horse, a lance, and the enemies don't have ranged weapons. Interpersonal relations are very important to maintain, since people who like you are more willing to do favours. I could go on for ages, but the only negatives for this game are based on age ; stiff animations, no facial animations or voice acting, etc. The graphics do the trick, and seem to be ageing well.

Mount and Blade is a strategy game for people that think strategy games aren't interactive enough, and I love that about it. It's not a pretty game, but mechanically it's one of the most interesting games I've ever played and the incredibly customizable difficulty makes it accessible to pretty much anyone. In fact, most things about the base game can be tailored to your own preferences, and mods expand that even further by allowing different themes and settings, although if I'm being honest maybe 1 in 5 mods function properly, never mind well.

Overall I'd highly recommend it if you want a slightly more true-to-life depiction of what it meant to be a leader of men in the feudal era.

If you have ever seen one of those medieval game ads that was a first person fighting in an army against an enemy, this is that game and more, you build your personal army by recruiting from villages, and you would think that the game would be super grindy with traveling and fighting to level up, but there is enough to keep you going, the big objective to take over the land of calradia really keeps me in it and the money. I have over 300 days in my new game and even when you think you have enough money, you don't and you have to pay troops and feed them. very immersive considering when it was made and I would say it's on par with a lot of big games out there, with that old graphic charm that is misleading making you think itll be some old basic fighting game. I own enterprises, manage villages, build armies, gain wealth, and respect from other lords in the kingdoms. I would say that considering all the tips and tricks that aren't explained in the tutorial, the learning curve is pretty steep but once you get the hang of it you can truly see why this game has the ratings it does.

You can push the battle size limit (max number of units in a battle) up to the maximum that your pc can handle just by editing a number in a config file, virtually up to infinity.

In Bannerlord (the new game) the way the game engine is coded makes that it has a hard cap, and it is at 2048 entities including horses, which means max cavalery battle is 512v512. One more soldier and the game will throw an exception at you and CTD.

For this reason and until it's fixed, Warband will remain the best Mount and Blade, and will still be a super cool game anyway after they eventually fix the new one.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

"Fun Game, the only bad part is when you first play it."

  I created this review years ago when I first initally played this game and enjoyed it. Finally years later I have 100% the game along with beating Viking Conquest and trying the waters of the other two expansions. With that said this is probably one of my favorite games of all time. I love the simple but hard to master combat that you can really test the skill ceiling of in MP. Even with my completionist status and a couple hundred hours I still suck in the MP lmao. That with the buildup from a single man trying to get by to becoming lord or even king of one of the kingdoms is such a difficult but fun progression. I love raiding other kingdoms to make profit and having to delicately select where to raid or who I can or can not fight as I help my kingdom expand and eventually take Calradia. It allows you to do so much that I didn't even know I could get married until 200 hours in and watching some reviews (thanks Sseth). This game has its jankyness with the exact systems of how things work, the graphics, and ai, but I think all of that gives it a charm that helps my experience overall in it. If those bother you as well you can install the countless mods it has that allow you to overall certain mechanics or change the setting of the world completely. I always go back to Native but do occasionally find it really fun to play around in Floris, LOTR TC, or the Japan TC. With all that said, I give it a 10/10 and if any of what I said interested you then I highly recommend you go play this butter-loving game.

>Naturally, i announce myself the holy Archbishop, Rychart. 
>He says you're either with me or against me. 
>Im with you.
>Gives me weapons, a horse, and 2 bodyguards. 
>I help him on his holy crusade to unite the map and sway the hearts and minds with religion.

>My brutal tactics oppress the population and eventually an uprising deposes the King.
>With the King and his army dispersed, they set their eyes to a new enemy. God's most holy servant, the Archbishop. 
>Get assassinated. 
>Respawn as a peasant.

It's B!tchwork: The Game

You're a b!tch.

You do work.

That's how Mount and Blade: Warband is played.

You grind. And grind. And grind. Doing the same thing over and over again, expecting a different result.

Every once in a while, the game screws you over. You take a loss, maybe even a significant loss to undo the hours of "progress" you've previously made.

It certainly doesn't help that finding things to do is a massive pain in the @$$. Quest givers move around the map constantly and are even taken out of play frequently. Quests are random. Some are easy and pay well. Some are needlessly difficult and pay $h!t. But you won't know until you ask someone to do more b!tchwork for them.

Then, when you're done with your b!tchwork, you have to go find the quest giver again. He could be across the map, or currently an enemy prisoner. Who knows? But good luck finding him. And if the time limit on your quest expires before you do? Well... sucks to be a b!tch.

Everything else you can do is completely random and pretty much entirely dependent on whatever's happening next to you on the map. 

Combat is rough and janky. AI pathfinding is silly. Controls are ridiculous. 

You could be playing a million other games, so why waste your time with Mount and Blade?

If you're really that desperate to do bitchwork, ask the local 7-11 if you can clean their bathrooms. Or pick up the dog $h!t in the park. Pull some weeds out of your neighbor's yard, or whatever.

If your game can't launch there is solution

BUT i have just fixed it (Jumping around like crazy) and i cant believe what the problem was for SOOO long time. Brother found this in a forum . I will post by whom as soon as i know to give credits.

"I solved this problem because I found your "Current language for non-unicode programs" should match your game's default language. e.g. You set up a chinese Mount&Blade but your non-unicode programs is English or others, your computer can't compile your game. Go "setting" - "Time & Language" - "Region" - "Additional date, time & regional settings"(right side) - "Change date, tiime, or number formats" - "Administrative" - "Change system locate". "
the only thing i added ,after following the instructions, at the last step there is a box saying : "Beta: Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support" and it must be checked!

edit will share it to other people having the same problem asap

I picked up the original three as a bundle quite a long time ago and started With Fire and Sword as it was the newer one but quickly switched to Warband, which in my mind is the highlight of the series. I am always a sucker for a game that allows you to start as a relative nobody and work your way up to something great. That is not the same as games that treat you like the dirty peasant you are, although those definitely have a place in my library. Warband, partially I believe due to its non-true historical setting allows me to step into another time and place that isn't just a fantasy world. I can play as the leader of a troop of bandits, maybe mercenaries, though let's be honest most of the time I either pledge to Swadia, or try to strike out as a new kingdom. This was my childhood game and I remember playing it for so long. I still do, this game offers amazing native. Sure, there are a lot of stuff missing there, but smart and talented modders did that. There are so many Warband mods out there, still coming. I will never forget this game, nor stop playing it.

This Game is lacking in graphics, however it makes up for that by being one of the best games ever. the perfect combination of challenging strategy and simple but fun fighting mechanics. If you like medieval games and strategy then you will like this game.

Calradia is a land of war split into several factions in which you become a part of. You may do whatever you would assume you could do in a Medieval Fantasy world and more. You can become a vassal, siege castles, raid villages, build an army, attack others, etc.. but the main premise is to conquer Calradia as your own sole kingdom. This is a daunting task and will take you many 100s, maybe thousands of hours of work to finish entirely. You must conquer every single castle, town, and village of all the other factions under your own name, uniting Calradia once and for all, so eternal peace is restored. This can technically be considered beating the game, even though there is not an official end screen. However, this is an extremely difficult thing to do, and if you do want to do this, it takes a lot of patience, skill, and ambition. It is truly an amazing feat. 

However, there is one minor thing that makes the game a bit less polished, and that is the graphics. To be quite honest, the graphics really are not very good. They are decent; it doesn't look like a NES game, but they aren't great. You can note however that the armor and weaponry does have some nice finer detail, but other than that, the game is not particularly graphically beautiful. 

The thing is though, every Warband player can easily ignore this fact because the gameplay is so amazing.

The gameplay is unlike any game I've ever played, and it's a game about really going from the lowest rung of society to the very top as a powerful king as just one of the goals. Starting from the very bottom as a peasant with maybe some leather armour and a few rag tag troops with farm tools as implements of war, then slowly building your way up through battle, looting your enemies, selling their spoils and wearing their better gear, gaining new troops through the recruit of prisoners and from the taverns and villages, narrowly winning close battles and seeing your character grow stronger, wealthier, more renowned and more respected, honorable, or villainous is indescribably satisfying. You go from a withering peasant who barely can afford a club to beat his way through the rugged, individualistic world to a mighty lord or king who has an army of 100s of powerful troops that can smash nearly anything in its way. You can buy enterprises to bolster your income. There's a whole trading system where you can buy and sell goods for higher prices dependent on the current supply. You can battle in tournaments, court ladies, conquer, raid, and destroy anything in your path in your pursuit to betterment. Even when you get to the heights of regal kingship, the very tip of the hierarchy, you still feel like there is so much to accomplish because suddenly you're targeted as a high value person who needs to be taken down. Your vassals can revolt, kingdoms will declare war on you, your kingdom can crumble without careful consideration. And, like I've said, you can apply so many different mods that add so many new features that freshen the game to a point where it almost never gets boring.

Another point I'd like to make is how the story-telling in this game works. Any companion you hire has an interesting story. The quests you partake in have interesting backstories. Companions can feud with each other. You can literally have assassins sent after you to murder you. Even in vanilla, the stories and narrative are interesting and give you a basis for the story that you yourself can create. This game really is the pinnacle of freedom, because you can literally almost do anything you could possibly want. Even if you don't care for the medieval era, you can get mods to play in the zombie apocalypse, WW2, fantasy settings with orcs and elves and goblins, LOTR, Star Wars...etc. There is almost any setting you could possibly want with any story you want to play through.

To show you even more good things about this game..its value. This game is only 20 dollars and is constantly on sale for extremely cheap; it's only about 5 dollars. This game is so worth the price because of the sheer amount of modifications you can apply to the game and the insanely huge amount of activities you can do. 1000s of hours can be spent in this game and you will still have fun with it.

This game has crack in it and the unending ambition to keep improving keeps you going for 100s of hours.

This game is excellent. If you like history, warfare/battle simulators, RPG's, action, and extreme progression, this is your game.

Estou fazendo isso, finalmente estou escrevendo uma resenha do meu jogo favorito de todos os tempos antes do lançamento do Bannerlord.

Mount & Blade: Warband é um dos melhores jogos já criados. Embora não pareça na frente, este jogo é extremamente complexo e profundo. Cada decisão que você toma tem uma reação e nenhuma jogada será a mesma. Você pode se sentar para jogar por uma hora e rapidamente se envolver com isso e se ver atacando a escória Swadian várias horas depois em um piscar de olhos. Isso é apenas no jogo single player básico também. Assim que você entra em mods e multiplayer, seu horizonte se expande exponencialmente. Você aprecia cada detalhe em uma intensa luta corpo a corpo e desenvolve as habilidades para superar seus oponentes. Ao longo dos meus 8 anos com quase 5000 horas e contando, não me arrependo de um único segundo do meu tempo jogando este jogo. É realmente uma obra-prima que nunca será recriada, nem mesmo em sua continuação em Bannerlord honestamente. Se este jogo não estiver em sua biblioteca com pelo menos 100 horas, você está efetuando um grande desserviço a si mesmo.

Well the first few hours into the game I had an absolute blast, the combat and the massive scale of the battles along with ragdollphysics and each character on the battlefield doing its own stuff ... that is truly amazing

The game promotes freedom, choosing whatever you like and being absolutley not restricted or even linked to a main story line, you are free to write your own story ... at least that is the theory

In reality it's is terribly restrictive, if you don't do what the game expects you to do within the first hour or so, you get fucked ... plain simple ... you keep wandering around with your 50 man army which looses all it's moral, keep paying bills you can't afford, running after enemys you are too slow to chase .... or wandering around for hours in forest where noone else is, visiting all the counts in search for a stupid quest which give you no money, or which is not scaled to your level ...

Strangely the bandit skrimishes were a good way of leveling and getting money, but for whatever reason 99% of bandits vanished after 4-6 hours into the game ?

See, the game expects you to do certain things in your area, then travel there or do that ....

To be honest I wanted to play a good guy in medieval times, maybe the game just wants to be realistic there and you need to burn every village and kill all peasants to get along .... but no I fell for their advertising of freedom of choice in this game

Costum battles are no good either, you only have a handfull of maps and the fun ends quite fast

UPDATE: After giving it another try, I can only say that the multiplaer community is full of little racists and the general experience there is that it is terribly unbalanced and everyone runs around with 2h weapons spamming overhead attacks for one hit kills .... singleplayer is still dull ... well all the M&B fanboys in the world can't convince me, this game sucks!

UPDATE 2: Viking Conquest is even worse somehow, eventhough the music and atmosphere is right!

Good strategy game, the Viking DLC adds more depth if you get bored of the base game.

GAMEPLAY:
What can I say about Mount & Blade? It is quite possibly the best RPG game created. I will first talk about the singleplayer campaign. Mount & Blade gives you the creative freedom to fabricate your character in any way you so well please. Whether you want to be a brigand raiding villages with your band of baddies, or a helpful person going around with your group, helping villagers and lords with menial tasks, or perhaps you want to be a vassal to a King, fighting battles and laying siege to castles in the name of your liege. Perhaps you want to be King commanding your own realm and warring with other Kingdoms expanding your power.

In Mount and Blade you start off as someone low on the social ladder, you can probably handle a sword deftly enough to vanquish your common brigand, but you certainly wouldn't be able to take on a knight. You can hire peasants from villages to join your war party and watch them rise in skill as they become knights on mounted horses or expert sharpshooters with bows or crossbows. Eventually, throughout the course of the game, you will have a powerful army that can crush big war parties led by Lords or Kings.

The combat in this game is relatively difficult, (especially in multiplayer). When first playing without automatic direction blocking you will very much find combat daunting, but don't let this dissuade you from playing, you will eventually get better at it to a point of being able to hold your own against most players. I'd say learning to combat in this game is one of the most fun things. Actual experience with other players is undoubtedly the best way to get better at fighting.

Moving on to the multiplayer side of the game, this is where the Napoleonic DLC comes more into the equation, you can partake in duels to better your fighting or you can fight in sieges and big battles against an enemy team. I can't speak for the vanilla Mount & Blade MP, however you can also partake in commander battles, commander battles is a type of game mode that leaves you in charge of a detachment of 30 men and you must command these men, alongside the rest of your team, to win a battle against an enemy team that are in the exact same position as you. There's all this and more to Mount & Blade MP.

If there's one thing that one must mention about this game it is the mods, you haven't played Mount & Blade properly if you haven't experimented with modding. One mod I must recommend is Gekokujo, in which the premise of the game is the same, other than the fact that you are in the Sengoku Jidai period of Japan. There are brand new weapons, armour, troops, and many other things that basically create a brand new game for you, (you can even get matchlock samurai units). Again I have to say if you are going to play Mount & Blade, you have to use mods.

STORY:
Your story is whatever you want it to be. However there is little bits of lore about the world of Calradia sprinkled in by companions and Lords, I'll let you discover it for yourself as not even I know everything about the background of Calradia.

AUDIO & MUSIC:
Upon opening Mount & Blade you are hit in the face by perhaps one of the most awestriking main themes ever created, it feels like being bombarded by a shockwave of awesome. The music in this game is very befitting to the type of game it is. The main theme begins with fanfares from trumpets, which gives you a heroic feeling. The texture of the music thickens which leaves you feeling overwhelmed by the possibilities of what is going to happen to you in your adventures through Calradia, and after roughly fifty seconds the music ends, the silence beckoning you to press the "start a new game" button.

The rest of the music throughout the game varies from calm, as you walk through villages and towns talking to lords and peasants alike, or chaotic and heroic as you make battle with brigands or lords. 

Mount & Blade has a great soundtrack, one that I shan't forget for a long time.

GRAPHICS:
The graphics are as to be expected from a 2010 game, but they absolutely do not take away from the immersive experience you will have. I think Mount & Blades aesthetic is what makes this game so much more different to all the other RPGs out there, you will never have a game as aesthetically alluring as this one.

Do you have a computer that can't run modern games? Do you want a fun game that you can sink endless hours into? Warband is the game for you. Even if you own a good PC, it's still well-worth the price, ESPECIALLY with all the mods on it. (Prophesy of Pendor is my personal favorite :) In this game, you can be a wandering mercenary, a humble trader, a ruthless bandit, a loyal vassal to a lord, a stalwart lord of your own, and can even ascent to be a King/Queen! The end game is uniting the entire continent under your banner. It's easier said than done. This game (Especially Pendor) is quite the challenge, and will likely take you multiple characters/playthroughs to see it right. Well worth the money. Buy it. Play it.

Mount & Blade: Warband is the game I have sunken the most hours in and continue to do so. It is an exceptionally fun game and the replay value is seemingly unending. The base game is fun but mods are truly where the fun is. I have spent probably 100 hours in the base game, 50 hours messing around in different mods, and 200+ hours playing the lotr mod. Naturally, for a game 10+ years old, it is a little clunky. The controls can be stiff at times, graphics are dated, and bugs occur. Nevertheless, there's just something satisfying about building up your own army, being a vassal, or creating your own kingdom, and fighting other massive armies. 

TLDR: Fun game, unending replay value, will probably be the game you go back to playing when you're bored.

There is a lot of good in Mount & Blade, but it is an uphill journey through slow, tedious, and unappealing gameplay. Everything in this game is slow. Going through the overworld, going through towns, etc. It takes forever and in my personal opinion, once you've done it once there isn't anything more you'll get out of doing it again. I guess I can see the appeal for people who want role-play and that kind of thing, but even then I really don't understand what you get out of it. It feels like the kind of game you are forced to mod and fine-tune to get an enjoyable experience. But...then its 60 hours later, you feel like you have enjoyed maybe 20 of those, and you really wish you would've spent that time doing literally anything else. 

Maybe you'll enjoy the game, some people obviously have. They call the combat innovative, realistic, etc. but I call it clunky, uninteresting, and tedious.

Yes, this game is a great design. While playing I always wanted to see features expanded and had no idea about Bannerlord. That said let me explain why this game is great.

The game itself is a basic set up at the start. You'll travel around and learn about how the game works. It's not terribly hard but in the first hour you'll immerse yourself with what is going on. You fight bandits and do simple missions from Lords or villagers. You can fight in tournaments and declare you victories to a lady when heading to the castle post event. 

There you'll meet lords and ladies. Either who want you dead or happy to meet someone new. Once your renown is know (150 renown) you'll now begin another stage of your adventure. You can become either a mercenary or pledge yourself to a King. Expected to fight in military events and so on. Though it is a bit cheesy. 

Marriage is limited to just marrying a lady of a family and securing ties but also it is spiced up when you can challenge another's hand to a duel of fates. Who ever wins will either win the love of the lady or you'll be scolded for it. That is clear prior to the choice made. 

Sieges and battles are kept at 150 pop in any case. Understand is is taking in the factor of 1 x 1 = % advantage. If you have more troop count youll gain more numbers in the battle. A ratio factor is made by the game allowing a small but 'fair' advantage. 

You can build your villages and towns and depending your engineering level it will decide how long it will take. Take care of your fiefs otherwise no money will be made. 


Many features in the game are great but limited. Bannerlord expands and has many reworks of the game I wished for. I never knew about bannerlord until 1 year prior of release and it has been a great design of improving and implementing all we wanted in Warband. But in saying that, this game still has an active and thriving modding community that has made wonderful useful or total conversion mods that you can enjoy.

Mount and Blade: Warband is a medieval combat CRPG set in Calradia and was made in the ancient days of 2010

-Graphics:
For 2010 they're alright, but nowdays they're just charmingly bad. Animations are smooth, the randomly generated faces of npcs and players are very oblivion-like, terrain is washed off and very blurry, towns and cities are copied and pasted all around. You would say that these qualities make them bad, but as I said, they are charming. They grow on you over time and you remember fondly the monstrous faces you encounter around the world. From me: this gets a 8/10 but from nowdays it would get a 6/10.

-Music and Sound: 
One thing that time didn't gnaw on, and was even made better as the years have passed. The warcries and lunging sounds with the gibberish talking is memorable. The music of every Mount and Blade game are spectacular and very nostalgic. There is just something special going around this dangerous world with a squad of mercenaries while some soothing strings play on your adventures. One of my favorite one is Mounted Snow terrain calm (Nice name isn't it).

-Gameplay and Atmosphere:
 Now this is the one part of the game that didn't age the best, even though it's still a nice experience.
The game is divided into a topdown boardgame-like map where you can go around, find some fights to participate in, go from town to town to trade or carry out missions, recruit mercenaries from towns or camps etc. it's very fun and engaing, seeing wars and battles take place and even helping your own faction in sieges and stuff is really fun. Other fun feature is that every save you make is different, so in one the Swadian towns and castles get ruined and one of their trade items like flux or something else go up in price because the demand is higher.
 The combat in the other end is fun for the first half. In the beginning you do most of the work, with a combat that is simple, you can hit in 4 different places and you have differing weapon types that specialize in different things, like axes kill shields good, and maces can stun, but after the first half of the game, you participate in fights less because you have an army that you need to use to fight of difficult battles, this is when the game becomes "who has better units and more of them". Also the AI is stupid, like really stupid.

Overall, I'd say this is a game worth buying, and it's really cheap too. For me, who has lots of nostalgia for this game, I'd say an 8/10 is fair, but at times I'd say it dips into 7/10. All around a classic and very nostalgic game.

As extensive as it is large Mount and Blade is a medieval simulator with a surpisingly large amount of control a player can make on the game world. The player is a foreigner that comes to the country of Calradia (an alternate medieval Europe) with the wares of your choice after creating your character. He or She could make their name as a trader within the world’s economy which changes in response to war which was common during the medieval era or work as a mercenary for any of the six kingdoms which would to many historical fans could draw parallels with historical kingdoms up until they become a vassal. Each of the player’s choices impacts the game as lords and your own compatriots react to robbing, fighting and supporting the peasants, and will sometimes affect how the lord’s view you. Thus is the problems with vassal systems. The game’s other systems open up as you start to receive land under your name and perhaps dream of being King/Queen where your enemies will not be the common thief but lords and their armies. Lord’s relations also changes realistically in respect to your position as king when the game switches from individual allegiances to managing an entire kingdom, entrusting its security to vassals that could defect if your go too far giving land carelessly. The game is an open world sandbox with all of this taking place within a single game and typically last 500-600 in game days, so while it is slow to build up the game allows players for a deep gameplay that makes each playthrough an experience in spite of its age. The Game also has an active multiplayer with players all over the world roleplaying as medieval era knights or a napoleanic soldier should you the game's fantastic Napoleanic Wars expansion, both optimized for PC for all around control in bayonet fights or when swinging a sword

Highly recommend this game for those who enjoy slow paced RPG's, especially if they love the medieval period.

tl;dr Mount & Blade: Warband is a fascinating sandbox/medieval simulation game which is basically unique in its niche. Despite its simplicity, there's a tremendous amount of depth. Mod support is incredible and the game is cheap anyway since it's on the older side. I highly recommend this game.

STORY
There isn't one, since it's a sandbox game. You, the player, create the story through your actions in Calradia. As a consequence, I can't really rate the game in this area. If you have no imagination, the game will be lame. But a player could also weave a thrilling and personal tale beyond anything a team of writers could devise. 

GAMEPLAY
The player character is a foreigner who has arrived in the vaguely medieval land of Calradia, which is split between 6 warring nations. From there, the player can choose to play in an abundance of different ways. They can eschew combat and try to play as a peaceful trader; they can jack their combat skills and become the most renowned or infamous warlord Calradia has ever seen. Marry into the nobility, work as a mercenary or swear yourself to a nation, even take over Calradia yourself; all these options are open to you. The world is dynamic and changes with both the player's actions and the movements of NPCs. The incredible freedom of gameplay against the backdrop of a world which changes with or without the player's input makes Warband incredibly deep. The game also has a simple but intuitive combat system with a similarly surprising amount of depth. It's not perfect, and there are a number of glitches which can force you to close and reopen the game, but overall Warband's gameplay is solid. However, it can also get very repetitive, particularly if you are playing "optimally." 8/10

LOOKS
This game was made in 2010 and it shows, but in all seriousness, who cares? That being said, yes, it didn't age well. Even when it first released there were presentation issues. Enemies hilariously spawn T-posing out of nowhere. The font is pretty ugly. So on and so forth. However, most of the animations are actually solid, and for that I give props. 3/10

VALUE
You could legitimately play this game forever. The modding community has magnified that by several factors. If you don't want to play in Calradia, you can play in Europe, or Japan, or Star Wars, or Middle-Earth. Modders have taken the framework Warband provides and made it even deeper with mods which change how the player manages relationships between lords, alter and balance combat, etc. And since the game was released in 2010, it costs a very reasonable $20. The value cannot be overstated. 10/10

OTHER NOTABLES

One of a kind game blending simple yet satisfying combat action with an utterly addicting gameplay loop of growing your party, making money in various different ways, and engaging in politics and power struggles in a living, breathing medieval sandbox. There are political figures and economic forces, wars and diplomacy that truly shape the nature of gameplay. You're able to play as a mercenary party, a trade caravan, a vassal of one of the distinctly designed and historically inspired factions, or even a group of mere bandits. The possibilities range from wandering as an individual to being the actual king of an actual kingdom, and leading your forces to conquer the entirety of the map.

Throughout this there are battles ranging from scraps with bandits and assassins to great sieges with hundreds of soldiers at battle. You control your own character and can lead your soldiers in specific formations and battle strategies to gain an edge on your AI foes. With the right troops, the right moves, perhaps the right terrain, you can surmount any foe.

The visuals are ugly even for its time, and there are some serious polish issues in vanilla, like the weirdness of getting knocked out, autoresolve, retreating from battle and thus resetting everyones' positions at will, and other weird bugs that you'll have to get used to as you play. This game is, after all, my favored example of Eurojank. However, many of these are corrected in mods. The mod community is thriving even today, and mods range from the smallest of enhancements to total overhaul mods to a variety of universes, ranging from Lord of the Rings to Game of Thrones, medieval Japan, fucking Touhou, and even original universes like in Prophecy of Pendor.

Most games set in the Medieval time period are fictional with magic, monsters, elves and other fantasy stuff in it. While that's totally fine the standalone expansion pack to the celebrated Mount & Blade game takes and continues to the opposite direction by going more realistic and historical while also getting you involved in both the politics as well as the large scale battles with you commanding your troops on the ground at the politically intriguing lands of Calradia once again. If you enjoyed the base game then this expansion pack will add even more to what you already like by enhancing visuals, adding a new faction the Sarranid Sultanate (Medieval Muslims), improved animations, bandit camps, improved combat gameplay (chamber blocking, kicking, time-limited couched lances, changing side of melee strikes, auto-blocking missiles with your shield and troop moral during combat); better balanced party system, better balanced food, more quest types, buy land even manage enterprises; found, command even rule your kingdom with ability for vassalage and lastly getting married. Multiplayer is now a thing too with up to 60-250 players/AI bots duking it out in class based customizable combat with a variety of game modes to pick from as well as Modding being much more easier then before. If you haven't played Mount & Blade before its quite literally make your own adventure in a giant sandbox third or first person action adventure role playing game where you decide your fate with words or the sword. The main feature is the large scale combat and realistic Medieval era world they made while its not the most authentic (plate armor losing to swords) it sure will punish those who just rush in to the fight without considering tactics and strategy. A ton of replayability each playthrough especially with mods and how random things can get in Calradia. Highly recommended for those who want to take a break from fantasy while still being in the Medieval epoch.

It's good, very good, but yeah, it's old.

It's from a different generation, another style of video-gaming. The art, the style, the dialogue, the gameplay and loop, are all from another time. 

But this is a timeless game. The mechanics work so well, the gampeplay is so solid it still holds to this day as an absolutely incredible experience, feeling smooth and fleshed out. Though, the game is complicated, and it does little after teaching you the very very basics (some fighting mechanics). The rest you have figure out on your own: Troop management, battle tactics, political choices, etc. Those more advanced mechanics are hard to figure out without help from a guide and the community, which are absolutely fantastic. 

You won't be sucked into an beautifully immersive open world with complex characters. 
There aren't fancy weapons, or shiny spells. 

There's just you, some weapons and armor, incredibly solid and fair mechanics under the hood, and an world for you to conquer. 

It's just a different style of game made for a simpler time. If that's what attracts you, get this. And you will be immersed in possibly the most robust medieval RPG game to have ever been made.
