Seeing as i have a huge amount of accumulated time I thought I'd write a review for this game... 

A lot of my time is in mods, but I still played the DLC(Viking Conquest also counts towards the base game) and the vanilla a lot. While it has it's flaws, and the start is almost ALWAYS slow and boring, I also think it's rather necessary. It gives you a great feeling of progression to try and solo a group of 10 looters and die, only to come back later and kill them all in one hit, taking 0 damage lol

Overall, while I admit, the game does have many flaws, for example, if you go ahead and start a kingdom too early, you might end up just being destroyed when all the kingdoms gang up on you and attack your towns with armies of 1000= soldiers lol. Also the game gets very boring near the end, when you're finally building up a big enough army to take over the world, the game sorta just... loses it's meaning(keep in mind, this takes a very long time to get to this point lol)

Well, enough about the negative, this is quite possibly my favorite game. And if i wasn't poor, i would be Bannerlord immediately, too bad it never goes on sale lol. I still play this from time to time, alternating mods and sometimes even just playing the diplomacy mod(which is base game with a few added QoL features). It has an awesome level of progression, you start off with a small group of 10 soldiers(it actually starts you with 1, but it's quick to recruit more) and gradually building up to an army of 300+. 

After all that exposition, for anyone that doesn't know this game, it is a mix of a strategy game and a first person/third person game. You move about on a world map with a small "unit" and when you encounter an enemy, it goes into a real time battle where you directly control your main solder while the other soldiers fight around you. Battles of up to 150 soldiers(I believe that's what it's limited to in base game, but some mods go way higher) and realistic weapons physics, for example, if you swing your sword but hit the enemy before your sword picks up speed, you will do much less damage, but if you charge at them while on a horse, you will do considerably more damage. Certainly never played any game like it, probably number one of my top favorite games, along with Kenshi and Rimworld(believe it or not, this game does have some minor similarities to those games)

Last note, while I am a long time player of this game, imo higher difficulties just make the game frustrating. Even in early levels on the easiest difficulty you can die in one or two hits if you're unlucky, so my advice is play it one 1/4 damage and poor AI quality, but idk, maybe some people like super frustratingly high difficulties lol

Warband is described as Mount and Blade's standalone expansion. This is literally the case. It is a significantly expanded version of the original and completely supersedes it. Everything that Mount & Blade had to offer is here, there is simply more of it. Mount & Blade is not easy to place using standard genre terminology. I have heard it called an action-RPG, with strategic and tactical elements. But the most relevant term I believe is sandbox. The concept of the game is enchantingly simple. The empire of Calradia is long gone, the lands it used to occupy are now the battleground of several factions fighting for supremacy. You are an adventurer that somehow ends up in this volatile land. That's it. Make your own own story, the world is your oyster. 

The game provides a dynamic world with different kingdoms fighting wars, vassals shifting allegiances and changing borders. The world is full of towns and villages that can be visited in pursuit of quests and activities. The player is encouraged to build their own retinue of loyal soldiers and seek fortune and glory in whatever way they please. You want to roam the map hunting bandits and protecting villagers? Or roam the map pillaging villages and robbing caravans? You want to join the faction wars as a mercenary for one king or another? Or perhaps swear fealty to one of those kings and gain your own land as a vassal? You want to start your own kingdom and bring Calradia to heel? You want to travel from town to town and participate in knight tourneys? Or start various industries? Or simply become a trader in pursuit of a good deal? You can do all that and more.

As can be inferred, the game takes its simple concept and elevates it to great heights, thanks to a series of complementing mechanics. That's why Warband is great. But, however deep or engaging its gameplay loop may be, its presentation is downright awful. Jankiness is the name of the game. Poor graphics, horrible interface that obstructs more than it helps, laughable animations, clipping, bugs and a generally amateurish feel complete the set. To say this game lacks polish is to say the Pacific ocean is slightly wet. This is really unfortunate, it tarnishes the experience. Many times I was caught by surprise by an event that was poorly explained, or simply got bored to tears waiting for that siege tower to slowly reach the walls. I can't help but wonder how much better Warband could have been if there was a mere modicum of polish.

In the end, do I recommend this game? Definitely yes. What fan of fantasy hasn't thought of experiencing what Warband has to offer? An open world that you can just roam free in. Janky or not, there is a lot to like here. It does help that the game has a significant number of mods too. The developers do in fact encourage people to try out mods. A possible concern would be that the true sequel to Mount & Blade, Bannerlords, is already in Early Access. If you don't mind incomplete games, perhaps that would be a better option long-term.

[h1] Medieval Childhood Game [/h1]

This was one of my first games, I fell in love with it in three different ways:

1° When I was a kiddo medieval design won me over for the aesthetics of the game, every day after my history classes I couldn't wait to get home and play and establish my own kingdom, it was one of the few games my father played with me too...

2° Around my teenage years, when I played it, the strategy of building a balanced army and how to do ambushes and sieges, the economy to maintain your army and improve your equipment and other things.

3° The last time I played it, the way you interact with npcs, you can get into fights with nobles, marry and run away with your spouse, rescue the nobles, interact with your unique followers with their own personalities, change lords to your side with your persuasion and military prowess. This kind of content being present in an old game, like a very old game, the graphics are really bad BUT I think it's amazing how they build a game this way when no one has done it something of this scale (total war is more city manager in the old days). Also the add-ons especially fire and sword I loved the gunpowder fights and fighting for my northern kingdom there.

P.S: Don't get me wrong, but you can fight with peasants so even being a villain in this game its ok and "fun"(avaible) UHSAUHAUHAUSHUAUASAHS.

With that said, this is one of my favorite medieval franchises, I can't wait to play Bannerlord and enjoy the improvements. :^)

The M&B series is unique in itself, allowing the player to do whatever they want without being bound to some main storyline allowing random stuff to happen such as being some psychopath burning down villages and bothering villagers to going up against all of the kingdoms by establishing your own kingdom!

Warband has to be my favourite compared to both the original Mount & Blade and Bannerlord for not only it's gameplay or it being easy to learn but it's modding community too, sure it's textures haven't aged well but it's soundtrack still sounds great.

Like you can go from playing a mod about Starwars, being in Europe during 1257ad and a 16th century Japan! Hell there's even a mod about World of Warcraft and LOTR! like i could go on forever about the amount of mods Warband has though your more bound to find more of  them on mod websites [b] (i'd recommend moddmb) [/b] rather than Warband's own workshop!

[u] (Although you'll have to have a file exacting program if your wanting to get mods of from modding sites that support Warband due to the mods being compressed but thankfully there's plenty of tutorials that should teach you on how to do it from Youtube & Steam guides) [/u]

[code]"I didn't have time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead."
- Mark Twain[/code]
Gonna be honest, I realize I'm going against the grain here. There's over 100k positive reviews so take this with a grain of salt.

My experience with [i]Mount and Blade[/i] was similar to that of a smoker to Malboros. It's not a good game by any means and yet I was utterly addicted to it. You assume the role of a noble within the continent of Calradia, with six factions warring to conquer it, sculpting an army and conquering territory. And, well, that's it. Perhaps my favorite bad game.

[h1]The Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]This is a very organic RPG, perhaps the truest form. No story - you write it yourself. It's like the nemesis system from [i]Shadow of Mordor[/i], blown up to over 200 individuals, kingdoms, factions and cities. 
[*]Party management is a lot of fun. My armies have always been something that I hand picked and oversaw
[*]Sieges are a blast, even if they've got huge bottlenecks and the AI has absolutely no idea what is going on
[*]Fief, castle, and city management is straightforward and self-sufficient without too much distraction from the core game loop.
[*]It feels like an authentic medieval experience. The art direction for models and score is on point.
[*]It was hilarious when the marshall let me marry his daughter, then defected, and was jailed in the castle with his daughter holding the key.
[*]Cranking up the difficulty doesn't require skill per se, but it does require a different mindset. I played with the difficulty and had an easy time finding where I was comfortable.
[*]There were lots of times where I was [b]deep[/b] into a power fantasy with a small but drilled army that could take anything on.
[/list]
[h1]The Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Graphically [i]Mount and Blade[/i] is not impressive at all, even when it released in 2010.
[*]Allied AI is super frustrating to work with since they can't count. If the sum of our armies exceeds one enemy, there are many instances where they'll still run away.
[*]The only line of dialogue is "YEARG", screamed dozens of times each battle. Well, maybe also a "My lord".
[*]Finding people, allies or enemies, is a huge chore and often leaves you like "but I was just there"
[*]The mid-game is boring and aimless. Late game is sluggish.
[*]If you're not in command of your faction, late game combat can be extremely cumbersome and boring. Like you can absolutely capture every castle by yourself but the AI will just swoop in while you're gone and undo all your progress.
[*]Battles are not significant enough. Without a place to stash enemies, they come back incredibly quickly. Once you have a town or castle, it's much easier to snowball an enemy which is why the mid game is so boring.
[*]The interface is bad. To the point that text will be on top of text and things highlight in lime green which is impossible to read at smaller font sizes.
[*]The book merchant's inventory never renews
[*]Combat areas look procedurally-generated and many locales are not enjoyable at all to fight in.
[*]This game is simple to the point that it feels barebones, like it isn't finished. While I liked the simplicity when getting started, I was constantly seeing places where I'd make improvements if I were a developer.
[/list]
[h1]The Indecisive[/h1]
[list]
[*]At its core, [i]Mount and Blade Warband[/i] is a huge grind. Speedruns are over 9 hours on the easiest difficulty and on harder difficulties it may take dozens at the shortest. Skim some other reviews and expect a single playthrough to take you at least 50 hours.
[*]The score isn't half bad but with how long it takes to get anywhere, you've heard everything for several hours when you're reaching the endgame.
[*]Combat is simple, but also feels somewhat unrefined. Blocking is borderline overpowered against AI whereas thrown weapons are almost always a hindrance. Attacking is based on the vector your mouse takes, so your camera will be going all over the place. But after a while, this gave it a bit of charm in ways that the simplicity of the overworld, dialogue, and progression failed.
[*]Couched lance damage hits like a Serbian father-in-law, which feels great to deliver but never feels fair to receive.
[*]Renown, honor, and right to rule are still systems that I don't entirely understand. Fortunately, you don't really need to.
[*]This game potentially has a lot of reading if you really want to know the lore. This reading is primarily functional and can change as your saves progress, so the lore can be hit or miss.
[*]Khergits specialize in horses, which makes them take twice as long to fight because of how annoying they can be. Playing as them is great!
[*]By the late game there has been a lot of flip-flopping between factions and from a cultural perspective, there is little to distinguish the combat style of one faction to another.
[*]If your horse goes down in battle, you're basically a potted plant.
[*]This game is highly moddable, but I haven't really explored that at all.
[/list]
[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
My first sesh was 13 hours of bliss. Once I knew what I was doing, however, the gameplay lost most of the wind in its sails. So why did I stick with the grind in such an underwhelming game?

Well, do you like [i]RuneScape[/i] for the numbers? Do you play [i]FIFA[/i] for the single-player campaign? There's an audience that this title is perfect for. Watching numbers slowly go up is satisfying. In this title, you're able to directly tie it to a power trip and the poor graphics, gameplay, and audio can seemingly melt away. While I loved it, I know plenty of people who wouldn't.

I'm glad it got a sequel that's addressing most of the cons. This game frequently goes on sale for less than 5 bucks, so if you want to test the waters this is a good choice. I never played the multiplayer or modded it, but there is more to explore which isn't addressed in this review.

All that being said, it's a different kind of grind than mainstream experiences will give you and unless that's your cup of tea, this game will come across as a bland hog of your time.

Mount & Blade is one of those games that you start playing and before you know it it's the middle of the night and you're going to be knackered at work tomorrow. It's addictive, and it's hard to really pinpoint why. 

You start off as a generic guy (or gal) in one of a few different factions' lands. You can recruit villagers from towns to join your little war party, meet companions (heroes with names who can join you) at taverns, trade resources between different areas, or even make a play at trying to achieve nobility - either by working your way up, serving a Lord until you can become one yourself, or through marriage, or probably through other means too. It's a really open ended game and I imagine most people will play this differently.

I always try to go down the Berserk route of being a very strong fighter with a small but skilled party of fighters. Being a mercenary for a nation and then impressing them by decisively winning key fights for them is a springboard to being named a vassal yourself, and then you can go on to try and make your own kingdom!

Or you can just roam around and kill bandits, defending the smaller villages from peril! It's really up to you.

I don't get the impression this game's graphics were anything special when it came out, and they're definitely not in 2022, but everything looks like what it is supposed to be and the game isn't 'ugly' or anything. Just shows it's age. I suggest playing Windowed as it's one of those games that tends to crash when you tab out/in.

mount and blade warband is a little bit of everything; character progress feels like little rpg, in battles you can give orders to your troops like in tactics games or simply lead your soldiers in to battle - after that ypu have to move soldiers, recruit more, feed them, keep their morale, upgrade castles, villages, recruiting lords, promoting companions that part feels more like strategy game for me
worldmap is divided to couple of regions with specific troops from nothern huscarls to nomad horse archers to noble knights to dessert mameluks

game starts with character creation (few questions about your character past leading to your skills and apperance) after that you can do whatever you want - game doesn't force ypu to anything but obviously more dedicated ways of playing is supporting one of factions, setting up rebelies against existing factions, or trying to run your own faction but yeah nobody is going to shout at you if youre going to attack caravanes all your time or if you decide to become merchant with some factories around world

early stage is so random due to your power and quests which you are supposed to do but you can't take because your faction is at war and you can't help them because formaly you're not their ally yet and you're too weak to fight on your own (or you're lucky enough to start on your own tho)
if you manage to get into middle stage in which youre strong enough to defend versus other noble lords or if you're already a vassal, then everthing including final stage should be more fun and less boring or even less annoying than early stages

after some hours doing most of the things over and over again game may become boring, and then it's time for jumping into steam workshop mods from simply diplomacy which will only upgrade the hard repetable aspect of native game to lord of the rigns, game of thrones or even star wars mods - complete conversions

also you don't need to start from the scratch always, there is option to import/export your character with all stats and with some gold

it's very hard to say anything bad about game which you love, but for sure companions which could be more interactive, more dynamic quests, more events like sickness, weather changes but most of that things you get with most popular and relased mods, and vanilla game is best for learning basics and how to play mount and blade warband

To this day in 2022, the community and playerbase remains very active in spite of the release of the sequel to Warband, namely Bannerlord. Solid fighting mechanics a la Age of Chivalry but in some ways enhanced, a Total War-esque level of strategy and troop leading in battles make for a great experience, and the module system achieve making this game very accessible to modding, which can go as far as to break what has been thought to be the boundaries of the game engine itself, not to forget the customization of the player character's face and equipment, both in single- and multiplayer. Still, while I personally adore Mount & Blade: Warband very much, it is not perfect. Gameplay and graphics wise, it feels and looks visibly old, which might deter people not as familiar with it from playing. Lighting remains one of the strongest aspects of the graphics but in every other way, for example textures, models and such, it falls flat these days. Even the HD texture update the game received a few years ago doesn't save it, and the shadows of NPC's and players being limited to what feels like 15 frames per second is slightly jarring. Still though, it is easy to overlook the graphical flaws with everything else that Warband provides. The multiplayer scene is still booming also, even more than that of Bannerlord at this time of writing.

The sea raiders said to me "God will decide your fate!".  They were supposed to sound intimidating, but I mumbled under my breath, "I am God, and your fate is already decided".  My cavalry trampled them, twice to be sure.  I reached my destination, a small impoverished village, where, allegedly, a hideous murderer was hiding.  It was he I was after.  Crossbow slung across my lap, loaded, I slowly trotted around scritinizing each villager.  There was one guy, standing where I would not have expected a villager to be standing.  Bit sus.  Had to park my ride to reach him.  I offered a simple question.  He gave the wrong answer.  Without aiming, the crossbow discharged into his chest, sword crumpled his skull.

A moment later I asked a village woman how was life.  She gave the right answer.  Almost bought a tear to my eye.

Mount and Blade: Warband is one of the greatest games ever made. It has some of the best melee & ranged combat in any game ever, great commander controls, a well crafted medieval world with lots of player freedom, and a huge modding scene. This lengthy review is only a basic overview. 

The combat of Mount and Blade: Warband is excellent as it is easy to quickly understand, but difficult to master. The game has a large number of melee weapons that can attack from a variety of different ranges and from up to 5 different directions. The default setting is that right click slowly automatically blocks attacks from any direction, but for higher level play blocking should be set to either mouse direction or keys because players and higher level AI enemies use fake outs and attacks from angles with jumps + spins. Weapons include many different kinds of swords, scimitars, two-handed swords, axes, two-handed axes pikes, hammers, maces, spears, lances, and many different types of shields. Lances can be couched while on horseback to do insane amounts of charge damage and weapons work differently against different types of armor. Ranged combat also has alot of depth as bows can do more damage and be fired while on horseback, but require a large amount of skillpoints to be put into the Power Draw and Horse Archery skills to access their increased utility over crossbows. Crossbows lock aim in place and can be fired like snipers from the start, while bows require leveling the skill to reach that accuracy. There are also thrown weapons like knives, javelins and throwing axes that have their own complexities. 

Mount and Blade is not just about fighting, but also about building and leading an army made up of many different kinds of units. The army command system is very basic, but it allows for skirmishing, flanking, rotating charges, and even hit & run tactics. By default commanding is done through the F1-F8 keys and the 1-8 keys with each key linked to menus that let you command different kind of units. Units and companion characters can also be rebranded to being different types of units. There are 6 different factions modeled off of historical medieval regions that each have their own specialized units and you can use any of them and even create mixed armies. Mount and Blade is probably the best game where you lead soldiers in battle. 

Alot of attention has clearly been paid to developing Calradia. Before you start you have to build and design a character. Skill points, weapon points, starting items & reputation are allocated based on the many different backgrounds you pick for your character as they age up to adulthood. Gender affects how the points are allocated and how your character is treated throughout the game. Calradia is a patriarchal society that gives women a harder time, but marrying a lord can also give your character a fast pass to riches. The backgrounds can be mixed and matched and most are affected by gender. The game has alot of optional text for those who want to learn, but these traditions, economic lessons, peoples concerns, and conflicts all manifest as mechanics. Money can be made by killing bandits, trading goods between cities & villages, investing in manufacturing, doing quests, fighting in tournaments and more. Players can set any goals, from conquering the whole of Calradia with themselves as monarch to making a fortune as a merchant or installing a pretender on a throne.The game has companions that all have their own skillset, backgrounds and dramas with other companions. The sheer number of different party skills makes creating a balanced party a good idea, but picking characters you like is also an option. 

Mount and Blade: Warband is a game that you can pour thousands of hours into without getting bored. Its limited number of skillpoints, large number of factions and political system justifies specialized characters and many different playthroughs. It has mods that fundamentally change the game and even represent epics the Sengoku Jidai, Viking Era, Romance of the Three Kingdoms,  and Lord of the Rings. Its eighteenth century combat mod had hundreds of players organizing into regiments for historical line battles and this eventually became its own DLC. This game has endless content for both singleplayer and multiplayer.

Every day, I wake up, boot Mount and Blade, and it that very moment, realize humanity's desperate desire for serenity, the same struggle which brings upon itself an insurmountable barrier, a barrier that will lead to the dichotomization of the human race itself. This flaw takes the form of Mount and Blade. Mount and Blade is humanities greatest sin, deplorable in all right, yet unable to end. Like a dying animal, I wish only to put it out of its misery, yet it struggles to live. Shall we continue this streak of sin, we might as well eliminate ourselves and our legacy as humans now. But not even the words of I or anyone else will not change the undying cycle. Why do we bother to try if all that awaits us and our forthcomings is great calamity? What a cruel farce of God.

I just can't picture a person who is alive right now and doesn't own it. You must be a teenager or super old. There are many attempts to surpass the heights that this game has achieved, and none have come close.

It's mods are equally impressive in their scope and variety. From modern warfare sims, which I have never even touched to warsword conquest (If you love warhammer, you can thank me later) to the prophecy of pendor. The limits are nearly endless.

I doubt the developers understood the ease of modding this game and it's basic integrity are what stood it apart from the masses of games out there. I cannot sing my praises of this game high enough.
This game is fun due to it being extremely big, very mod friendly, and brings back the funny graphics of older games, highly recommend it to other players if they are into medieval times.

overall, game is quite good, a certified classic, but the tournaments are too unforgiving
